on 4 SeptemberThe city of New York as seen from the ISS on 11 SeptemberScientists find they don’t know how fast the universe is expandingTo resolve the problem, further research will be required to understand whether we have simply not detected another piece of the puzzle, or are simply a statistical fluctuation. But they could also suggest that we are lacking a new physics that is yet to be discovered, they write.The shape of the universe affects some of our most fundamental understanding of existence, deciding the geometry of how the cosmos is assembled.In a flat universe, parallel lines will run forever, just like if you draw a set of them onto a sheet of paper. But if it is not flat, they intersect: if you draw two parallel lines onto a spherical object like a football, for instance, they run into each other on the other side.Scientists have long been convinced the universe was shaped like that sheet of paper. But the new paper suggests that could be wrong, and it is not flat but rather closed.The authors of the new paper say that if it is correct that the data from the Planck telescope suggests we are inside of a closed universe, it introduces a new problem for modern cosmology.Part of the issue is a consequence of the fact that our current precise understanding of the cosmos is arrived it by combining different datasets – measuring different things in different ways – together. Scientists generally assume that those datasets are consistent, and come from the same cosmological model.But some of those datasets are actually in contradiction with each other. There has been intense discussion of exactly how fast the universe is expanding, for instance, and measurements from the Planck telescope have been in contradiction with others.Scientists have tried to reconcile these differences with alterations to our understanding of physics, or to suggest that there might not be quite such a difference as thought. But those attempts have generally relied on the assumption of a flat universe, the authors write, and that may be incorrect.The researchers revealed their findings in a paper, 'Planck evidence for a closed Universe and a possible crisis for cosmology', which has just been published in&nbspNature Astronomy.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Log in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.President once said climate change was ‘hoax’ invented by ChineseThe United States has formally told the United Nations&nbspit is pulling out of the Paris climate accord, a deal that was signed by Donald Trump’s predecessor, Barack Obama.While Mr Trump, who has long denied the existence of man made climate change, had promised to withdraw the US from the 2015 deal, the formal process only got underway when Mike Pompeo said he had submitted a notice to the United Nations.The notice, filed on Monday and which claimed the 2015 deal signed by 200 countries placed an “unfair economic burden” on the US economy, does not become official for one year.“Today we begin the formal process of withdrawing from the Paris Agreement,” the secretary of state said on Twitter.&nbsp“The US is proud of our record as a world leader in reducing all emissions, fostering resilience, growing our economy, and ensuring energy for our citizens. Ours is a realistic and pragmatic model.”Created with Sketch.Finding food on the front line of climate change Show all 17Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.117 Balkisa Zakow, 25, with her twins Hassan and Ousseni, Tombokiery village, NigerAt nine months’ pregnant with twins Balkisa Zakow, 25, feared she wouldn’t have the energy to give birth. title: four day week microsoft japan trial productivity work life balance
story: Log in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Technology company saves money in trial by cutting electricity consumption by 23 per centA&nbspMicrosoft Japan trial into improving work-life balance has found productivity increased by 40 per cent when employees were given a four-day working week.Full-time employees were allowed to take five consecutive Fridays off in August with pay in the research project.Meetings were also shortened to a maximum of 30 minutes and remote online conferences were encouraged over face-to-face meetings to cut down on travel time.In addition to the increase in productivity, Microsoft Japan was able to save money in the trial by reducing electricity consumption by 23 per cent and reducing printed paper by 59 per cent compared to August 2018.The results showed 92 per cent of employees were pleased with the four-day week and a similar trial is planned for winter, which will encourage workers to be “more flexible” with their hours.Created with Sketch.World news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Women run down a sand dune as they take part in the desert trek Rose Trip Maroc in the erg Chebbi near Merzouga. title: brexit party votes corbyn no10
story: Nigel Farage will not be Prime Minister. Nor is he remotely likely to hold the balance of power.There is no longer a route to the No Deal Brexit he wants. Nor any prospect of Boris Johnson caving to his demands for a pact, destroying the Tories’ unity. And it is patently untrue to say Boris’s deal is not Brexit. The Tory ERG simply wouldn’t back itso.It will end our membership, payments and free movement and extract us from the customs union and single market, with no “backstop” keeping us half-in. We would trade freely as an independent nation. And Boris alone can get us out. The sole alternative as PM is Corbyn, and he will keep us in the EU for ever.In a few constituencies Farage’s party could hurt Labour more than the Tories. Overall it is FAR more likely to prevent Boris winning the majority which is vital to delivering Brexit and without which it is lost. That is why Farage’s ultimatum to the PM delighted Labour.Two by-elections — in Peterborough and Brecon, both of which the Tories should have won — were gted to Labour and the Lib Dems by Brexit Party votes. On December , those could put Corbyn in Downing Street in a Remain coalition.At which point Farage’s legacy won’t just be that his vanity wrecked his le’s work.That a party he founded with only one aim, a real Brexit, became the very instrument of the project’s destruction.He will be remembered as the right-wing maverick who handed anti-Semitic, anti-Western Marxists an unprecedented chance to plunder the world’s fth-largest economy. The Sun admires Farage.His pressure brought about the referendum AND a better deal. But he could now be the author of a double national catastrophe.He and his voters should think again.WE’VE heard it all now.Labour’s Tom ­Watson, of all people, insists broadcasters must combat the Tories’ “fake news”.That’s the same Tom Watson who destroyed lives spreading a paedophile’s lies.Whose party’s campaign centres on a blatant fiction about Boris “selling the NHS to Trump”.Whose leader lies endlessly about his terrorist sympathies and anti-Semitism — then sinisterly orders reporters: “Just report what we say.”These charlatans lecture journalists about the truth.But they themselves are strangers to it.Andthey took power, Press freedom would be a nostalgic memory.The Sun joins everyone rooting for Owen and England’s rugby heroes.Best of ruck, lads!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris must convince tory virgins
story: My mum was old-school tribal Labour, a militant dinner lady, always happy to go on strike when her union asked, at home on the picket line, her lelong allegiance to the Labour Party as unchanging as the colour of her eyes.My dad had no love for the Labour Party — he was a corner-shop greengrocer who believed Labour only cared about their militant brothers in the big unions — but Dad despised the Tories with a passion, seeing them as the protectors of big business, rich bosses and inherited privilege.There were plenty of Tory Prime Ministers in Downing Street when I was growing up. But they never got one vote from our house. And I have been thinking of my parents over the past few days and wondering: Would they have broken the habit of a letime and voted for Boris Johnson Because that is the key to who wins this General Election. We hear a lot about how Boris has to woo “Workington Man” — “an older, white, non-graduate male from the north of England with an interest in rugby league and a tendency to vote Labour”. But it is not just Workington Man who holds the keys to  Downing Street now.From one end of the country to the other, it is all those voters such as my mum and dad, who never voted Tory before. That is who Boris has to woo and win. Those millions of Tory virgins.The polls all suggest there is a massive majority for parties which favour leaving the European Union. Butthat vote is split between the Tories and Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party, then we don’t get Brexit.We get Jeremy Corbyn gurning on the steps of No. We get an economy in ruins. We get Venezuela without the nice weather.  But splitting the Leave vote is not a strategy for delivering Brexit. It is a cast-iron guarantee that Brexit is cancelled. If you want to see the result of the Referendum, you have to vote Tory.My mum and dad would not have recognised the rotten Labour Party of today. They would have been baffled, then angered, by the total absence of anything resembling patriotism among Corbyn and his Marxist mob.My parents would have scratched their heads at Labour’s immigration policy — to allow “as much free movement as possible” — not because they disliked foreigners but because they thought the identity of their country was worth preserving.My folks would never have trusted a grizzled old Marxist like John McDonnell with their hard-earned wages. They would have been wary of seeing the police force supervised by Diane Abbott.They would have noted Emily Thornberry sneering at the flag of St George while happily adorning herself in the EU flag. They would not understand how Corbyn could happily lick the sandals of Hamas, Hezbollah and the IRA.My parents — the kind of people who fought our wars, paid their taxes for a letime and built this country up from the rubble — would not have spat on this Labour Party. And after years of seeing Parliament place itself above the people, they would have crawled across broken glass to get to the polling booth on December .My parents believed in democracy. They had no doubts about the importance of voting. They would never have voted for Jeremy Corbyn. But would they have seen that the Conservative Party is now their natural home That’s your historic task now, Boris — convince the millions of working-class patriots like my mum and dad that you truly understand their lives. Andyou can do that, you will win a landslide.We have heard a lot about the failure of fire chiefs and their policy of “stay put” which added to the death toll of .But there has not been nearly enough focus on the heroism of the firefighters who were there on that hellish night.Firefighters put their lives on the line for strangers.Yes, that is their job. But their job deserves our unequivocal respect and gratitude.PRESENTER Samira Ahmed is suing her employers at the BBC for £, in pay because she received a fraction of what Jeremy Vine was paid for allegedly “similar” work.I like Samira Ahmed on Newswatch and wish her well.But Jeremy Vine is far more of a household name. And when it comes to getting paid, star power matters more than gender.I would like to be banking the same royalty cheques for my books as JK Rowling. But best not to hold my breath.IN the Eighties I did a story on the politan Police’s Vice Squad, which logged the contents of the pornographic videos they seized while watching the raunchy action in fast-forward.I can still recall the bored, joyless expressions of the young Vice Squad coppers as they yawned through all that fast-forwarded filth.Now Netflix is offering the same sort of thing – aallowing viewers to watch shows at up to one-and-a-half times the normal speed. Don’t bother.If it’s not worth watching in real time, it’s not worth watching at all.THERE are million dog owners in the UK and I can’t have been the only one who cringed to hear President Trump boasting that IS monster Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi had “died like a dog”. And exactly how does a dog die, Mr President In my experience, a dog dies surrounded by humans who feel as though they have just had their heart torn out. A dog dies surrounded by love. A dog dies bitterly mourned by the family it leaves behind.According to Trump, the IS leader, “whimpered, cried and screamed like a coward . . . in utter fear, panic and dread”. My dog is not going out of this world like that. When our Stan finally goes, many years from now, he will be in my arms and looking in my eyes.Death will be painless and peaceful. It will be a moment of love and grief. Who writes your lousy material, Donald  All this “dying like a dog” rubbish felt stupidly off-the-cuff.While the world is mightily glad to see the back of a mass murderer, the florid violence of Donald Trump’s language sounded exactly like the kind of crass rhetoric we hear from terrorists.The President’s sneering “died like a dog” line was particularly misjudged because American special forces were helped in their ultra-dangerous mission by military search dogs.They pursued al-Baghdadi right up to the moment he detonated his suicide vest, injuring one of the brave dogs – a Belgian Malinois named Conan – who will be honoured at the White House next week.Kill all the terrorists you like, Mr President. But there is really no need to talk like one.THE traditional Guy Fawkes Night celebrations of my childhood have largely been replaced by Halloween.This makes me incredibly sad, although my we says Halloween is far less dangerous than all the bonfires and bangers of my boyhood.But did you see this outfit Craig Revel Horwood sported on Halloween ROBBIE WILLIAMS, , has challenged Liam Gallagher, , to a boxing match.Really not recommended at their age. How long is it since Britpop   years Stick to a game of draughts, Robbie.I WAS forced to play rugby at school and always hated it.But I have fallen in love with the sport at this glorious World Cup in Japan.But North kept running – or hobbling – and STILL made the tackle.I do hope our soft Premier League footballers have been watching.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: john legend baby its cold outside peak woke
story: Granted, anything that celebrates a man trying to ply a woman with booze in order to persuade her to stay the night sounds all wrong in . Happily, though, most of us know that, these days, coercion and force in the bedroom are not only ­unromantic but unacceptable.The offending lyrics in the song, which is a duet, are uttered by the female voice, which sings: “I simply must go, the answer is no” . . . only for the man she is singing to to hand her a drink — and for her to question what is in it. Obviously not good on any level. But this song was written in  .It was a hit during a time when sex was for marriage, and women weren’t actually allowed to express any active interest in men so had to feign modesty at all times. In the s and s, before the Pill was introduced, that dance of reluctance and “persuasion” was part of the courting process and the whole process of seduction was based on women pretending they weren’t interested only to be ­persuaded that they were.But look how dferent things are now.Also, let’s face it, when you get the magnying glass out, there are plenty of storylines from the past that don’t quite measure up to the standards of . Look at James Bond, who basically sexually assaults Honor Blackman’s ­character Pussy Galorein the movie Goldfinger.Or the song Every Breath You Take and the film Love Actually, both of which feature a stalker as the romantic lead. And when you think about it, Daniel Cleaver’s courting of Bridget Jones really just boils down to ­sexual harassment.There are countless other examples of “romantic” plots which are very dodgy indeed by current standards but, at the time, we all lapped them up. And don’t even get me started on the lyrics of rap songs that are being played today which routinely talk about killing and raping women. Now that is grim.But instead of allowing this song to exist as the relic from the past, soul singer John Legend and Kelly Clarkson have rewritten it. Their version now includes the lines, “What will my friends think If I have one more drink  ”.That is instead of “The neighbours might think,   Say what’s in this drink  .  Legend describes his version as having “a new-found sensitivity in the #MeToo era”. I’d put it a dferent way and say he is ­trying to re-write history.Last year a radio station in Ohio announced it would stop playing the original because of ­complaints from listeners saying the song, “didn’t have a place in modern music”. That’s fine. No one needs to play itpeople are offended by it. But the idea that we can airbrush the fact that it existed in the first place is ridiculous and I worry we are all in danger of trying too hard to be PC.The risk is we become so vanilla, so afraid of upsetting everyone with our view, that we stop speaking our mind, which is a form of societal repression. Yes, it’s good to stand up for what you believe in, but taking offence at the lyrics of a song more than  years old might not be the best cause to bat for.Everything has a context, andwe aren’t careful we will all be so worried about how “woke” we are that we will forget our own views and how to express them.PARENTS everywhere will be reassured to learn that even when you are a sporting hero your kids still think you are a bit of an embarrassment.Peter Crouch said in an interview yesterday that his daughter, Sophia, who is eight, initially asked him to stay outside when he dropped her off at summer camp – because the other kids were laughing about how tall he is .The thing is, as any parent will confirm,it wasn’t his height she would have found another reason that he had to stay outside, whether it be his shoes, coat or haircut.In fact, don’t worry Peter, as they get older they get embarrassed about you just for breathing.MILLIONS of motorists use their mobile phones while they drive. Thirty-five per cent of drivers under the age of , and  per cent of all drivers, admitted to taking their eyes off the road to check texts, email or social media, an RAC survey reports.But the current law means reckless drivers can only be prosecutedthey are caught using hand-held phones to call or text. Meanwhile, those who take photos or scroll through music playlists are exempt from punishment.So police have struggled to enforce the law because they are often unable to prove exactly what drivers are using their phones for. Bear in mind thata driver looks at their phone for just two seconds while travelling at mph, they will cover ft blind, drastically increasing their chance of an accident.So I’m fully behind plans for a ban on even touching a mobile phone while driving, which were announced – drivers take note – on Friday. It is thought the ban could be in place by spring next year.Drivers caught holding phones to browse social media, or even input a sat-nav location, now face six points and a fine of up to £. But how anyone can be complacent enough to check Insta while in charge of a moving metal box that can kill people is beyond me.I have not driven for ten years – I walk or get the Tube – but my kids do and it really bothers methey even so much as glance at their phones. There is no doubt that it is distracting – and dangerous for the driver, but also to others. So this proposed new law is nothing but a good thing as far as I’m concerned.I’VE never been one to embrace dressing up for Halloween or any other kind of forced fun.Sorryyou think that makes me sound like a killjoy, but one thing I have noticed with each passing year is the sexualising of Halloween going off the scales.Forget wizards, goblins and ghouls – every celebrity event seems to be populated only with sexy vampires, sexy ghosts and sexy witches. Witness Heidi Klum’s Frankenstein costume at her annual Halloween party in New York this week.The dress code seems to be wear what you like as long as it’s thigh-high, PVC or a bikini – with some fake blood. Dressing up should be banned – I haven’t done it since I was seven.ENGLAND’S poor rugby team. Yesterday they lost in the final of the World Cup after being fined for their response to the Kiwi pre-match Haka in the semi-final.Owen Farrell and Co stood in a “V” formation while the Haka went on. But it turns out they were supposed to remain in their own half, and some players didn’t.New Zealand’s Haka is all about intimidating the opposition. But the opposition are not allowed to respond The Haka is a dance about cutting off people’s heads.But it was England’s harmless response of standing still and forming a V for Victory – which I thought was brilliant – that was reprimanded.MY goodness, Rosie Huntington- Whiteley looks utterly gorgeous in her underwear.MS using her as a model is possibly its best marketing decision ever.You only have to look at her wearing nothing but white lace to think thatyou buy the same set, some of her beauty might rub off on you.I loved the comment from Cheryl Tweedy in response to Rosie’s Insta post: “And where do we get that body ”Nowonly that, too, was available to buy from MS.LOVED reading the stories this week from Angela Kelly, who dressed the Queen for  years.I particularly liked how she helped to avoid disaster at the  Commonwealth Games in Kuala Lumpur after the Queen’s hat arrived at the last minute. Her Majesty had been due to wear the hat as she officially closed the games but was distraught to find that it was unsuitable.I wouldn’t normally bother reading tittle-tattle stories about the Queen, but knowing that she has consented for them to be told I am really enjoying them.Also, the closest this great lady has got to making a mistake in  years is to wear her hat the wrong way round . . . which speaks volumes about her, doesn’t it Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stakes election boris blur rival
story: A crudely glorious image, painted yesterday by BoJo’s ex-mayoral aide Katie Perrior, sums up the extraordinary reach this Old Etonian posh boy has into the hearts of ­Britain’s working classes.It explains why Labour MPs are petried by the threat to their careers from millions of Leave-voting voters snubbed by the metropolitan elite.With poll leads up to  per cent, sky-high personal ratings and an overwhelming desire to see Brexit done, this is an election Boris Johnson should win by a landslide.We can surely count on the sound common sense of the British people to save us from anti-Semitic left-wing revolutionary Jeremy Corbyn.Yes, but . . .  Theresa May taught us the hard way about jumping to conclusions.All elections are perilous. Nobody can be sure how this Battle for Britain will pan out, any more than in .Tory election manager Isaac Levido told staff this week: “There is a steep and narrow path to victory.”Another aide says: “It is unknowable. This is fraught with danger.”Polls are all over the place, some showing an easily blown Tory lead of six per cent — less than Theresa May’s before she lost her majority.Momentum Labour has made a flying start with social media, bombarding targeted voters with eye-catching and wildly misleading messages — just as it did so successfully in .“You would think the Tory machine might have learned from that debacle, but they haven’t,” says an insider. “And you can’t build a new system overnight from scratch.”The challenge for the Tories is to define the battle lines within the first two weeks.“If it is a choice between Boris and Brexit or a second referendum — or even a third referendum — we are in a good place,” says an insider.But with five parties in this fight — the Tories, Labour, Lib Dems, Brexit Party and SNP — lines rapidly blur.Tory rebels such as Phil Hammond can also wreak havoc by standing as independents.Even Boris’s own ,-majority Uxbridge marginal is under threat from a bizarre invasion of Extinction Rebellion and Stop HS protesters.Nigel Farage, stung by Boris’s successful EU deal, has stunningly over-reached, threatening to field  Brexit Party candidates — although he won’t risk standing himself.His wrecking ball move has backfired among old allies including Leave campaign partner Arron Banks and one-time Ukip MP Douglas Carswell.His own party chiefs are in revolt, with Farage under pressure to back down fast.Cash donors have begun deserting and pro-Brexiteers are voting with their feet.One Sun reader, Brian Pearsall — a “paid-up Brexit Party supporter” — tells me: “I will be backing Boris. Mr Farage is beginning to annoy me. If he wants us to get out he should put candidates only in seats where the Tories have no chance of winning. What the hell’s got into him ”Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson has also misjudged the national mood by junking Brexit altogether — and campaigning to rejoin the EU.Her party has slipped in the polls and she is offering pacts to a ragbag of Greens, Plaid Cymru and any other minority group who might offer a hand.Yet every vote picked up by Swinson and Farage in Tory target marginals opens the door to a Labour advance.The stakes in this General Election have never been higher — or clearer. More than million adults voted in  to leave the European Union.Unless they have changed their minds, this is their last chance of seeing that wish come true.No more ritual humiliation of humble MPs who incur his wrath or ministers who dare challenge his petty tyranny.Parliament will take a while to recover its ­dignity after a torrid ten-year political trauma. story: Satellite TV engineer Simon Nolan, , claims he was left disabled and can no longer climb ladders or steps to install dishes.He told how the seat caved in leaving him in agony at The Gipsy Hill Tavern, in south London.The married father-of-four, of Upper Norwood, south London, had to have four operations and have a metal plate put in his his shattered right ankle.He said his weak ankle then caused him to fall down a flight of stairs four years after the barstool mishap, injuring his spine, and leading to back surgery in .As well as hitting his work, Mr Nolan says his injuries mean he can no longer play football with his son.He is suing Cityglen Pub Company Ltd, the owners of the Gipsy Hill Tavern, with his lawyers valuing his compensation claim at up to £m in court documents.Mr Nolan says he has now switched the focus of his work to fiber-optics so he can avoid ladder work, and a large proportion of his claim is for loss of earnings, Central London County Court heard.The pub admitted liability for the stool accident but say the huge £m payout is not justied.James Laughland, for the pub company, said he should get a much smaller payout of around £, outside court.Mr Laughland also cast doubt on whether Mr Nolan really cannot use ladders anymore.He claimed: “Recent jobs undertaken by Mr Nolan will likely have involved the use of ladders or small step ladders.”Judge Baucher reserved her judgement on the case at the end of a three-day hearing, to be given at a later date.He said: “I don’t get to do any activities with my children whatsoever, apart from swimming.“I used to be a keen cyclist, now I can’t play football with my son. title: new speaker lindsay hoyle replaces john bercow
story: The favourite replaces isive former Speaker John Bercow, who quit the post last week after a decade in the seat.The MP for Chorley beat Chris Bryant by  votes in the fourth and final round.In the final round of votes, Sir Lindsay, formerly a deputy to Mr Bercow, got  while fellow Labour MP Chris Bryant received .Sir Lindsay will replace Mr Bercow, who left the role after a decade which has been viewed as a time of reform but also controversy.He will now have to resign as a Labour MP to take up the impartial post.Speaking after the result, Sir Lindsay, , distanced himself from his showboat predecessor.Sir Lindsay, who is widely popular and respected by colleagues, said: I will be neutral. I will be transparent.This House will change but it will change for the better.He also paid tribute to his daughter Natalie Lewis-Hoyle, , who died in  and whom he said his family misses a great deal.Sir Lindsay was reluctantly dragged to his chair as part of a tradition dating back to the days when speakers could be sentenced to deaththey displeased the monarch.He is a colourful character who owns a parrot named Boris after the PM, a rottwelier named Gordon after the former Labour PM, a tortoise called Maggie after the former Tory PM and a Patterdale terrier named Betty after former Speaker Bettey Boothroyd.He is known for his friendly manner when dealing with MPs, in contrast to the dressing downs and theatrical grandstanding of his recently departed predecessor.Prime Minister Boris Johnson paid tribute to the new Speaker saying he prevailed over an extremely strong field.He added: The kindliness of the Speaker is absolutely critical to our confidence and the way we behave.And Mr Speaker, over the years I have observed that you have many good qualities, and Im sure you will stick up for backbenchers in the way that you have proposed, and Im sure that you will adhere to a strict Newtonian concept of time in PMQs.Mr Bercow denied Brexit bias but clashed with the government and strongly opposed Mr Johnsons attempt to suspend Parliament for five weeks as the Halloween Brexit deadline approached.Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn also congratulated Sir Lindsay and joked about the photograph posted online at the weekend of Hoyle apparently watching the rugby cup final while, at the same time, not watching the television.He said he would need eyes in the back of your head in his role as Speaker.Seven candidates were originally in the running.Four of the speaker candidates were women - Eleanor Laing, Rosie Winterton, Harriet Harman and Meg Hillier - but the winner was a man, just like all but one of his  predecessors.Labour MP Meg Hillier and Tory Sir Edward were knocked out in the first round of the contest after receiving  and  votes respectively.Having received the least number of votes, Dame Rosie had to leave the contest in the second round of voting.Tory MPs feared Remainer parties would rally behind Labours veteran MP Harriet Harman, who was seen as a continuity Bercow candidate.But she dropped out following the second round of voting after winning just  votes.Conservative Dame Eleanor finished last in the third ballot.Speaking after the result she said she was proud of Mr Hoyle.She tweeted: Many congratulations to @LindsayHoyle_MP on becoming Speaker of the @HouseofCommons. Weve worked together, as deputies, for six years and have been great friends. Proud of you! E.In his pitch earlier today, Sir Lindsay highlighted his experience as a deputy speaker for nine years and stressed the need to allow backbench MPs to hold those in power to account.Sir Lindsay also said the Commons was not a club whereof service takes priority, adding: The person who walked through that door yesterday is just as important to their constituents - their voice must be heard as well - and the pecking order ought not to be there, it is about equality.Sir Lindsay also vowed to push on with security reforms to keep MPs, their families, staff and the Commons safe.Mr Bercow, , departed the Speakers chair on October .He entered Parliament in  and held several shadow ministerial positions before taking the Speakers chair on June  , promising to serve no more than nine years in total.He abandoned that commitment ahead of the  snap election, but allegations of bullying by former members of his staff, denied by the Speaker, led to fresh calls for him to quit.In recent months he also came under fire for a series of controversial Brexit rulings in the chamber, which were widely considered to favour Remain supporters.

title: apprentice bbc box ticking
story: Nothing, except the words “TO THE RIVER” and a dirty great arrow, written on to a wall, about a metre from their heads.So they pause for a few seconds, look around, then scamper off in completely the wrong direction.The tip of the stupidity iceberg, as it transpired, on last week’s episode of The Apprentice, where they’ve been delivering this sort of comedy gold for  series now and, for about  of them, have had to put up with people assuring us: “It’s past its sell-by date.”One year they’ll be right, as well.But not this one, which has thrown up another wonderful selection of candidates with a whole iety of ­personality flaws and business skills, ranging from the competent, Flump-voiced Iasha ­Masood, right the way down to Ryan-Mark Parsons, the camp Michael McIntyre clone who Lord Sugar correctly labelled “a weather cock”. Evenwe can argue about the “weather” bit.Two contestants, though, go straight into the all-time Apprentice Hall Of Fame, alongside the greats like Paul Torrisi and Stuart Baggs.First is Cockney barrow boy Thomas Skinner, who sticks out among the boys like Ray Winstone in a touring production of Priscilla, Queen Of The Desert, and has turned out to be a lot more likeable than I was expecting.The second, though, most certainly hasn’t. For she is Lottie Lion, the librarian and wine snob who’s given to quoting Shakespeare: “For though she is but little she is a massive pain in the a**e.” Or words to that effect.All your worst office nightmares rolled into one, this girl. An undermining, ­passive-aggressive crawler who can swivel on a sixpence, depending on which way Lord Sugar’s wind is blowing.“In business there is no room for ­gambling.” “Hang on. Business is a gamble. You don’t take risks, you get nowhere.” “Yes, risk-taking is important, Lord Sugar.”Lottie’s also not helped by the fact she’s often right and most certainly wasn’t to blame for the failure of the scavenger hunt task which disintegrated, in ­shameful fashion, right at the start when team Empower’s Pamela Laird asked: “Does anyone know when the Second World War started ” Silence. They didn’t know when it started, ­finished, or even what side was responsible for killing Biggie and Tupac.A media meltdown followed, yet, amid the general despair, no one bothered to thank The Apprentice for the public ­service of flagging up this ignorance, because that’s not what happens with this show. Instead, it gets accused of stuff.This year, inevitably, it’s been called racist and claims have been made that the first four candidates were sacked due to their skin colour, rather than the fact they were completely useless or ­produced a “bespoke ­corporate ­lollipop” that looked more like a vibrator.It’s only Twitter that’s saying these things, of course, but they need to be quashed as the BBC is actually dumb enough to listen to these imbeciles and forget Sugar’s first winner was Tim Campbell and his show is about the only place on the network where black and minority ethnic people will be treated entirely on their merits.Get rid of The Apprentice and, I guarantee you, its ­precious and entertaining hours will be filled with the same mollycoddling, box-ticking, ­condescending, right-on ­b*****ks that fills most of the rest of the Beeb’s output.Treasure this show while you still can .The One Show, Matt Baker: “I’m very much looking forward to talking about your play, Meera title: dolly parton books for schools campaign
story: And now the country music icon, , is backing The Sun’s Books For Schools campaign, as it is a cause close to her heart.She has been putting books into the hands of children since she launched her Imagination Library in her home state of Tennessee in .The superstar, who was inspired to promote reading by her illiterate father Lee Parton, said last night: “I applaud your effort with Books For Schools. Access to books at any age is the key to loving to read and loving to learn.“Most of us have a clear memory of reading that one book that opened the door to seek more knowledge.“The right book at the right time alters a le.”Her beloved dad died in  aged . Last year she gave away her hundred millionth book.Dolly says: “My Daddy told me he was more proud of the Imagination Library than anything I’d ever done. I feel the same way because I truly believe this effort will last many years after I am gone.”Dolly’s ambitious book scheme has expanded all across the US, Canada, Australia and the UK, with Rotherham the first British town to sign up in .So she jumped at the chance to support our initiative, which has seen us team up with publisher HarperCollins to give away up to £million-worth of brilliant books to schools.New figures from the National Literacy Trust show a drop of more than five per cent in the number of primary-aged children who read every day compared to last year. And only  per cent of primary children read outside of school.We want to reverse these trends. Each primary school that successfully registers and collects enough tokens will receive a case of Collins Big Cat reading books containing more than  titles, worth more than £.Dolly’s Imagination Library sees children whose families sign up posted free books, funded via charitable giving.The singer says: “We’re trying to bring this gt to all children, whether they are from Scotland or Mississippi. Whether they are rich or poor. Or whether they live in towns or live in the country.“I am all about the values we all share in this world — love, respect, acceptance, integrity and commitment.”Born in The Great Smoky Mountains, Dolly was the fourth of  children to parents Avie and Lee.She says she is incredibly proud that her dad lived long enough to hear kids call her “The Book Lady”.Dolly adds: “This all starts with my daddy. He was a smart, smart man but he could not read or write. He never had the chance to go to school because he was a working man from day one. I could see how his inability to read or write held him back.“So I thought, ‘One day I am going to try to do something so all kids would at least have the opportunity to love books and to love reading’.”Children from big mountain families like Dolly’s dad often didn’t get the chance to go to school, and Dolly believes he could have done so much morehe wasn’t illiterate.Her loving parents encouraged Dolly to escape her “dirt poor existence” — largely thanks to her love of music and books. By six she was performing in her local church and at eight she had started to write songs.But she didn’t like school — with other kids picking on her because of her ragged clothes. She recalled once: “A lot of the parents didn’t want their kids running with me because I looked so cheap and tacky.”Books, however, offered an escape from her harsh youth.After the Bible, Dolly remembers the first book she read was The Little Engine That Could, a s American fairytale used to teach children the value of optimism and hard work. She says: “I have always loved its message of ‘I think I can’. What a wonderful way to encourage children to dream and to believe in themselves.“When I was growing up in the hills of East Tennessee, I knew my dreams would come true. I know there are children everywhere with their own dreams. They dream of becoming a doctor or an inventor or a minister.“Who knows, maybe there is a little girl whose dream is to be a writer and singer. But the seeds of these dreams are often found in books — and the seeds you help plant in your community can grow across the world.”Reading, according to Dolly, is the bedrock you need to write. She has written more than , songs, including Whitney Houston’s  global smash I Will Always Love You, has won a Grammy and has been nominated for two Oscars for her songwriting.Dolly, who in  read Louise Yates’ Dog Loves Books on CBeebies’ Bedtime Stories, says reading keeps her mind sharp as well as underpinning her music. She reads at least one book a week.Her favourites include Water For Elephants by Sara Gruen and The Count Of Monte Cristo by Alexandre Dumas. She has said previously: “I’ve just always been a reader. There’s a part of my brain that can kind of think of other things while I am reading. It does relax my body, and I’ve always just loved to read.“I think, with kids, too, with the books that they read, it kind of inspires you to dream. If you can dream, that’ll lead you to success and to other things.”Dolly’s achievements outstrip even her wildest dreams. As well as her musical accolades, she has also appeared in box office hits including  To  in  and Steel Magnolias in , while her US theme park Dollywood attracts .million visitors a year.But she reckons the best accolade is the delight experienced by children she gives books to from the age of five.When asked about her legacy, Dolly displays the razor-sharp wit loved by her fans. She quips: “I hope that  years from now people will say two things about me — first, that I had just a little bit to do with making the world a better place.“And, ‘Dang, she looks good for her age!’”. title: type 1 5 diabetes lada signs
story: But experts say thousands could have been misdiagnosed - or going undiagnosed - because of a new form of diabetes.Studies suggest that  per cent of people with type  diabetes - or around , - could have type . diabetes.Also known as latent autoimmune diabetes of adulthood , type . straddles the lestyle-related type  and type , an autoimmune condition.Its not actually classied as a separate type of diabetes at the moment, but medical research is ongoing to pinpoint what makes it dferent from the types we do know about.But experts warn that because many doctors are unaware of Lada, people are going misdiagnosed with type  diabetes.Professor David Leslie, a consultant endocrinologist and a professor of diabetes and autoimmunity at Queen Mary University of London, told the Daily Mail: Lada affects a very signicant number of people — it is three times more prevalent than type  diabetes in adults.Studies suggest between one per cent and two per cent of the UK population will develop it.Patients with Lada are often not well managed because they are misdiagnosed as type  — I see a lot of agitated patients who are really struggling to manage their blood sugar levels despite following medical advice.Professor Olov Rolandsson, a world-leading expert in Lada and diabetes researcher at Umea University in Sweden, also told the newspaper that people are missing out on the right treatment, which raises the risk of complications including heart disease and eye problems.Diabetes is a condition where someone has too much glucose – a type of sugar – in their blood.When people don’t have diabetes their blood sugar levels are controlled by insulin produced in their pancreas.If someone has diabetes, they’re either not producing insulin, or the insulin they do produce can’t work properly or there isn’t enough of it.This means that sugar builds up in their blood and can’t get into the cells of their body where it’s used for fuel.Type , is an autoimmune disease, which develops when the insulin-producing cells in the pancreas have been destroyed and the body is unable to produce it.Its treated by injecting insulin or using a pump multiple times a day.Type , the most common form of the condition, is when the body doesnt make enough insulin or the insulin it makes doesnt work properly.Some people can manage it with a healthy diet, regular physical activity and,they need to, by losing weight.But the longer someone has type , the more likely it is that they will need medication.Type . shares characteristics of both and, earlier this year, the World Health Organisation recognised it as a hybrid form of diabetes.As of yet, the cause of Lada is unknown but experts think that some genes might put people at higher risk.Unlike being overweight - a major risk factor for type  - people with Lada tend to be a healthy weight.Patients are usually diagnosed between the ages of  and  - older than typical for type  but relatively young for type .The symptoms are the same as both kinds of diabetes:Symptoms generally come on much slower than they do with type  - over months rather than weeks - but are more obvious and quicker than type .There isnt yet a definite, agreed way of treating Lada but research by Action Lada is looking into how common it is and how best to look after it.Until this study shares its findings, most healthcare professionals title: labour brexit sir keir starmer leave or remain
story: As Jeremy Corbyn prepares for a major speech today, the partys Brexit chief was unable to explain the partys official policy.Speaking on Good Morning Britain today, Sir Keir said it wasnt important what side he was on.The leftie party want to renegotiate Brexit in just three months and put it to another vote, but have refused to say which side they would support.Hosts Piers Morgan and Susana Reid tried to press him on what he would do in a future referendum -the party got their way.And what are you going to campaign on in that referendum , Susanna quizzed him.I need to knowIm going to vote for you - what do you believe in But Sir Keir replied: In a sense, what I am going to campaign for is secondary, what we are saying is, its for the country now to decide.It comes as:Susanna continued to press him, asking: Im voting for you... do you want to Leave or Remain Do you want to Remain  So am I voting to stay in the EU I want to be clear what Labours policy is! Am I leaving or Remaining And she blasted him for saying he would likely campaign against his own deal, adding: How can it be a really good dealyoure going to vote against it It would mean a third Brexit extension past January , and a six month period of renegotiating ANOTHER deal and a second vote.Sr Keir would only say hes already made clear what his position was on Brexit - he supports Remaining in the EU - and admitting there wasnt a version of Brexit he could support.MP Jame Berry said this morning: Surely @UKLabour can’t keep this up until polling day Mr Corbyn will accuse Boris today of trying to hijack Brexit and deliver Thatcherism on steroids.He was mocked last night for claiming that a trade deal with the US would allow maggots to be put in Brits orange juices.But Cabinet minister Michael Gove insisted again that there will be no lowering of any of our food standards after we leave the EU.Boris has today demanded Jeremy Corbyn come clean on Brexit and reveal whether he would cancel ithe became PM.

title: jacob rees mogg grenfell common sense
story: The Tory MP saidhe was in a building blaze, he would leave whatever the fire brigade said.But the politician has been slammed over his comments about the fire that killed more than  people inside the West London building block in June .Mr Rees-Mogg told LBC host Nick Ferrari: The more ones read over the weekend about the report and about the chances of people surviving,you just ignore what youre told and leave you are so much safer.And I thinkeither of us were in a fire, whatever the fire brigade said, we would leave the burning building.It just seems the common sense thing to do. And it is such a tragedy that that didnt happen.A recent inquiry found residents had been told to stay put inside the tower block for longer than they should have, rather than telling them to escape.Yvette Williams, chair of the campaign group JusticeGrenfell, said the politicians comments were appalling.She told The Mirror: This is an appalling statement to make but unsurprisingly symptomatic of Rees Moggs ilk.Rees-Mogg has a privileged background, what is his experience of living in social housing  How many tower blocks has he lived in To suggest that those who followed his partys instructions were not using common sense is an absolute insult.Ahmet Chellat, who lost five family members in the horric fire, also called on Rees-Mogg to apologise.Mr Rees-Moggs comments have caused outrage in the Commons with Labour MPs calling them “shocking” and “appalling”.Jeremy Corbyn said: “What possesses someone to react to an entirely avoidable tragedy like Grenfell by saying the victims lacked common sense “People were terried, many died trying to escape. Jacob Rees Mogg must apologise for these crass and insensitive comments immediately.”David Lammy, who had a friend who died in the tragic blaze, said: “How dare you insult and denigrate those who died in Grenfell Tower Jacob Rees-Mogg “The victims of this crime of gross negligence followed the instructions they were given by the fire authorities. Do not blame them.“Your arrogance and condescension is monstrous.Lib Dem MP Sam Gyimah said: “Insensitive and disgraceful for Jacob Rees-Mogg to suggest the victims of the Grenfell tragedy lacked ‘common sense’.“Our duty as public servants is for the truth to be laid bare, for justice to be done, and to ensure this never happens again.”“They were told to stay where they were by the fire service, who were acting on national guidelines. He must apologise.”Mr Rees-Mogg offered his profound apology for the comments this morning.He said: What I meant to say is that I would have also listened to the fire brigade’s advice to stay and wait at the time. ‘However, with what we know now and with hindsight I wouldn’t and I don’t think anyone  would.What’s so sad is that the advice given overrides common sense because everybody would want to leave a burning building.I would hate to upset the people of GrenfellI was unclear in my comments. ‘With hindsight and after reading the report no one would follow that advice. That’s the great tragedy.Read more: https:metro    jacob-rees-mogg-says-grenfell-victims-lacked-common-sense-staying-put-  itoarticle.amp.share.top itocbshareTwitter: https:twitter UK | Facebook: https:www.facebook UK It comes after a two year inquiry slammed the London Fire Brigades handling of the tragedy.It found that few people may have diedkey decisions had been made earlier, saying systemic failures had been made by the LFB.Sir Martin Moore-Bick criticised the LFB for its stay put strategy when residents were told to stay in their flats by  operators and firefighters for nearly two hours.The fire broke out just before am and the strategy was abandoned at .am.Sir Martin said: That decision could and should have been made between .am and .am and would be likely to have resulted in fewer fatalities.The best part of an hour was lost before Assistant Commissioner Roe revoked the stay put advice.However, Martin Blunden, the head of Scotlands fire service, said it was impossible to say whether more lives could have been saved.In a series of Tweets, he said: To say that more lives could have been saved is impossible to say at this stage and it is disappointing to read such a conclusion.I do not believe blaming LFBs commissioner or any staff is fair or correct.I understand the desire of those mourning to apportion blame and find out why.Matt Wrack, general secretary of the Fire Brigades Union, has also questioned the inquiry process.He said no one was trying to avoid scrutiny, but suggested the ordering of the inquiry was completely back to front and did not focus on the issues of the buildings construction.He added: The truth is that the fire spread the way it did because it was wrapped in flammable cladding.The firefighters turned up after that had happened, after the building had already been turned, in reality, into a death trap.Since the reports release, London Fire Commissioner Dany Cotton expressed her deepest sorrow at not being able to save everyone from the fire.We are lobbying for major building regulation change and urgent research into ‘buildings that fail’ on fire safety, which leaves the national ‘stay put’ strategy no longer viable. We will never give up until all of the changes we are calling for to protect residents have been made.We have and will continue to fully assist the Grenfell Tower Inquiry to understand what happened in order to learn and prevent such a tragedy ever happening again.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: general election lib dems claim
story: NewsGeneral election: Lib Dems claim theyd pump £bn ‘Remain Bonus’ into public servicesThe party, who want to cancel Brexit, are launching their election campaign this morningShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe Lib Dems are demanding Ms Swinsons inclusion so an unequivocal Remain-backing voice is heard in the November  debate "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Liberal Democrats have vowed to put a £ billion Remain bonus into public servicesthey win the General Election . The party said scrapping Brexit will generate billions for public finances because they say remaining in the European Union will mean the economy will grow faster than under Brexit, and will lead to higher GDP.The Lib Dems forecast that the economy will be .% larger in -Brexit is stopped than it would be under the Boris Johnsonaposs Brexit deal, reaping a idend of £bn over five years from higher economic growth and resulting tax receipts. Deputy leader Sir Ed Davey told BBC Radio aposs Today programme that the Lib Dems actually think these are quite cautious figures, adding that all the independent forecasters were clear that there will be a big boostwe stay. Paul Johnson, from the independent Institute for Fiscal Studies, said it was a reasonable calculation in line with their own forecasts, adding: We could expect the economy to be biggerwe were to remain and this assumes a relatively modest effectanything, although obviously subject to a huge amount of uncertainty. Launching their election campaign, leader Jo Swinson is expected to say: The Liberal Democrats are the only party standing up to stop Brexit and build a brighter future for the UK.   Brexit has taken far longer and cost far more than anyone said it would. But any form of Brexit will damage our jobs, our economy and our public services, starving them of vital cash as the economy struggles along. The Liberal Democrats will stop Brexit and then use the £ billion Remain bonus to invest in our public services. Ms Swinson is currently in a battle to be included in the leadership debates - despite being the fourth biggest party. According to the New Statesman, Chief Executive Mike Dixon and MP Chuka Umunna met with ITV executives last night, telling them “the party believed Swinson’s exclusion was unlawful … and that legal action would followthey did not budge.”  Jo  Swinson aposs insistence she could be the next prime minister has raised eyebrows, but under her leadership the Liberal Democrats have risen to poll heights rarely seen since the peak of Clegg-mania almost a decade ago.

title: modern guy fawkes parliament
story: NewsopinionWhat would we make of a modern day Guy Fawkeswe bumped into him under Parliament  years ago, a war veteran angered by broken promises stood in the undercroft of the Houses of Parliament with  barrels of gunpowderShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailImagine you find an Afghanistan war veteran with a bomb under the Houses of Parliament. It’s just you, him, and the bomb, and you chat to him so you can buy some time in which you hope someone will come along, call the police, do the decent thing. So you talk to the soldier. There are lots of things he could be angry about with the people currently sitting above you – electoral fraud, using the NHS as a weapon, Brexiters campaigning against Brexit, Remainers who canapost agree on remaining – but the thing he is livid about is the Armed Forces Covenant. Not the idea of it, which is to ensure military personnel suffer no disadvantage due to their service, and sometimes get preferential treatment because of it. Nor the way it was enshrined in law in  with much fanfare, and the then-Prime Minister promising to “treat people with the dignity they deserve”.    No, he’s angry about the fact that within a year of it being made law, Parliament pissed on it. He’s angry that war veterans like him were made redundant just days before they qualied for a pension, while politicians facing reform to their own pensions got a higher salary to make up for it. Heaposs angry that veterans already investigated and exonerated of war crimes face being investigated again, even when no fresh evidence has been produced, and despite official promises it would stop. And heaposs furious that the veterans who gave their lives and their health for Queen and country - and in some cases, that of their wives and children as well - are still being ignored. Survivors of Cold War radiation experiments have been told evidence of their genetic damage is inconclusive that they must prove an injury sustained  years ago and that, eventhey do, they might be asked to prove it a second time.    Heaposs angry that ex-forces people still face barriers in finding jobs, homes, and mental health support. A study last year showed , veterans had psychological problems, , were in prison, and another , had no permanent address. He knows that everyone suffered in the past decade of cuts to public services. But he points out that those who are more in need of them always suffer most, and that only half of veterans who need that help ever ask for it. Heaposs particularly angry about the current governmentaposs commitment to the covenant, and the debt of honour it represents. He remarks bitterly that theyaposve finally signed it,  years on, and all that means is that the Tory party is now eligible for an employer recognition award. Oh, and theyaposve updated the the website.    Heaposs angry at the state of military housing,  years after the government said selling it off was a grand idea. Heaposs furious at the way his family had to go on a council waiting list. At how,they rent privately, a grasping landlord will rack up the rent for a building unfit for human habitation while their benefit is slashed. At how politicians call people who have to live in those homes scroungers, and say they should be put down. Heaposs angry at a Defence Select Committee report which said the Ministry of Defence was immoral and incompetent, and at a minimum income requirement for immigrants which blocks Commonwealth soldiers settling in the country they shed blood for. He quotes the committee chairman, who said: Every year we take evidence on the implementation of the Armed Forces Covenant, and every year we report similar complaints. The Government is failing in its moral obligation towards those who serve or have served in our armed forces. Heaposs angry about his mates killed for want of proper equipment, at a private defence industry quite literally make a killing with state-funded trips to dictatorial regimes, and heaposs angry at mealy-mouthed letters from politicians thanking him for his service and telling him thereaposs nothing they can do. He says politicians stand with the armed forces when it suits them, but turn their backs when it costs.    As he talks you realise youaposre angry, too. Youaposre angry about a Parliament that stopped governing in the nationaposs interest, and spent  years arguing over a thing that could not be done, purely because theyaposd staked their careers on it. Youaposre angry about allies who behave like enemies, knighthoods for men who hit women, a vice-admiral who consorted with a paedophile rapist yet keeps his pension, and his rank. Youaposre angry that because the people who took it upon themselves to run the country are unable to do so, youaposve been asked to re-elect Islamophobes, anti-Semites, incompetents and rabble-rousers so they can have another go at cocking things up, on a starting salary of £, a year.    You donapost like politicians pitting you against your neighbours because of how they pray or the colour of their skin. Youaposre perplexed about schools that have to shut down one day a week, about a NHS winter crisis that lasts all year, about a minimum wage which isnapost enough to live on. You thought all that crap was supposed to be over, by now. You remember how you were promised electoral reform in  and it never materialised. You wonder about the worth of a system that tells the critically ill to get up and work. You wonder how disabled people can have a better le without the allowances they need to pay for independent living.You realise that many veterans are disabled. And they are given the same crappy treatment as everyone , and often have to fight harder to be compensated by the employer who put them in harmaposs way.    You think about at your local postmaster, corner shop owner, launderette, binman, cabbie, cleaner, nurse, teaching assistant, council operative and heaven knows who  and wonder how, precisely, we’ll manage without migrants, and whoaposll be coming up with the points-based system youaposre told is such a great idea. Perhaps you look at your own bloodline. Perhaps you look at the history books. Perhaps, in the words of those who talk of sedition, treachery and surrender, you hear the echoes of bad people from bad times. You think about the fact .million people who could vote last time didn’t bother. You remind yourself thereaposs more than a million people missing from the electoral register - who should be on it, could be on it, but donapost see the point. You stand there, feeling angry, and think about how  years ago a war veteran with  yearsapos fighting behind him, who worshipped the same God in a dferent way, who felt oppressed and angry about promises his rulers had made and broken, stood in the undercroft of the Houses of Parliament with  barrels of gunpowder, some coal and firewood, and matches in his pocket.    You think about how that veteran was seized and dragged before the king, how he and his fellow plotters were tortured with the rack and other instruments for  weeks to produce confessions, and how after a show trial they were taken to the yard outside Parliament so the politicians could watch as they were hung by the neck, cut down while still alive, castrated, disembowelled, and cut into pieces. Perhaps you know enough to remember that despite injuries so bad he could barely sign his own confession, Guy Fawkes was brave and quick enough to jump from the scaffold before the executioner could stop him, breaking his own neck and saving himself the extra agonies the state wanted to inflict. You wonder why we still celebrate the capture, torture and death of that man with a bonfire and fireworks, why we have forgotten that it was once laid down in law we had to do so whether we agreed or not, and that for centuries his desperation was used to persecute others who shared his faith.    You wonder how we all forgot why he was so angry, or that after he was gone the oppression for people like him simply got worse, and lasted for more than  years. You remind yourself we live in a country where Catholics were banned from marrying senior Royals until , all because Henry VIII took against them. Perhaps youaposd also wonder what the authorities would do to that Afghanistan veteranhe was caught red-handed with his bomb under Parliament, and how it would compare to what they would dohe was Muslim. You look over your shoulder at the door, and youaposre glad no-oneaposs come along yet. Maybe you wish him luck, and tell him that as Fawkes said on the rack a desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy. First photos of how temporary House of Commons will look in £BILLION refurb   Maybe you will try to talk him out of it, or go to find a policeman in the hope heaposll get help and the people who put themselves above will finally listen to those left below. Perhaps youaposre prepared to be optimistic about his chances of getting the help he was promised, and that he needs. Me  I think Iaposd quietly turn around, close the door, stick my elbow in the fire alarm and then let him get on with it.

title: tories delivered zero 200000 starter
story: NewsThe Tories have delivered zero of the , starter homes they promised in None. Zip. Zilch. New official figures show the £ billion project has delivered precisely no homes for first time buyers since it was announced four years agoShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsSee this  This is a house being built. None of this has happened "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories have delivered zero of the , starter homes they promised in . Official figures released today reveal the £ billion project to build homes exclusively for first time buyers has resulted in precisely none actually being built. The commitment was made in the partyaposs  election manesto, which said they would be sold exclusively to first-time buyers under the age of , in a bid to help young people take their first step on the property ladder. And it was backed up by £. billion being made available to support the delivery of the first , homes in that yearaposs Spending Review. But four years on, the National Audit Officesaid that, to date, no starter homes have actually been built.  Successive Tory housing ministers have claimed work was set to commence on the first starter homes. And none of their claims have proven to be true. In , then-Housing Minister Brandon Lewis - now an immigration minister - said: We announced a £. billion funding package to support the delivery of up to , starter homes. Of this funding £. billion will - in the first instance – be made available to remediate or assemble brownfield land to deliver at least , starter homes through the Starter Homes Land Fund. No starter homes were built.    In , then-Housing Minister Gavin Barwell - who was later Theresa Mayaposs chief of staff and has now been installed in the House of Lords as Baron Barwell - claimed the first homes would be built this year. He said: Thousands of new homes backed with financial support will help more first time buyers into home ownership. They will be built exclusively for first-time buyers between  and  years old at a discount of at least % below market value. The first wave of  local authority partnerships – selected on the basis of their potential for early delivery – will spearhead schemes. No starter homes were built.    While the Housing and Planning Act  created the statutory framework for the project to go ahead, the NAO said the relevant sections of the legislation has yet to come into force. But it said the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Governmentnow no longer has a budget dedicated to the starter homes project. Funding which had been earmarked for the scheme has instead been spent on acquiring and preparing brownfield sites for housing more generally - some of which was affordable housing. Between - and -, the MHCLG and its agencies spent £ million preparing land originally intended for starter homes.    The NAO said that, while it was possible developers had built and sold some properties which met the starter home criteria, legally they could not be marketed as such until the MHCLG had put place the necessary secondary legislation. The chairwoman of the Commons Public Accounts Committee, Meg Hillier, said: Despite setting aside over £ billion to build , new starter homes, none were built.

While Boris Johnson had already promised a probe by the end of the year, the Tory leader has been very careful to say it wonapost just be about Islamophobia. Instead, speaking to reporters in September, the Prime Minister said it would also comprise of prejudice and discrimination of other kinds. Campaigners claim this is downgrading an investigation and taking the focus off Islamophobia.    Mr Gove appeared to drop the conditions about other forms of prejudice when he spoke to BBC Radio aposs Today programme. He said this morning: We will have an independent inquiry into Islamophobia and it will be established before the end of the year. Yet after he spoke, multiple Tory sources told the Mirror they were unaware of any sht back to an Islamophobia-only inqury. And Mr Gove also told the BBC: We will have our own investigation into Islamophobia and prejudice. This may suggest the net is still widened far beyond anti-Muslim prejudice.It comes five months after Boris Johnsonaposs leadership rival Sajid Javid bounced fellow candidates into backing a full, independent inquiry into Tory Islamophobia.  After loudly inviting MPs including Boris Johnson to agree an external probe during a TV debate, he said: “Itaposs great that we all agree on that.”Yet weeks later Boris Johnson threw the probe into doubt by saying it would be a general investigation into all types of prejudice and discrimination, including antisemitism.Tory chiefs also repeatedly refused to reveal how many members they had suspended over alleged Islamophobia, despite a string of cases being reported to the party.And Tory minister Kwasi Kwarteng even suggested a full independent probe wasnapost necessary. He said in September: I think the party has enough structure and discipline and focus to try and deal with this problem in the first instance.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLindsay Hoyle, the newly elected Speaker of the House of Commons, has taught his pet parrot Boris to shout “order order!” Also in the new Speaker’s menagerie are a Patterdale terrier named after former Speaker Betty Boothroyd, a rottweiler named Gordon, cats named Dennis and Patrick and a tortoise named Maggie. Sir Lindsay, knighted in  for for parliamentary and political services, prompted raised eyebrows recently, when he posted a bizarre picture of himself watching the Rugby World Cup final in which he was facing away from the TV, beside a distant cup of tea no human could reach.    The Lancashire-born businessman went to private Lordaposs College in Bolton and ran his own screen-printing firm before becoming an MP in . He has been a Deputy Speaker for nine years where his no-nonsense manner led to clashes with MPs - including telling off the SNP for singing EU anthem Ode to Joy in . In the same week he had a fierce clash with ex-SNP leader Alex Salmond, with the pair shouting at each other across the chamber over time slots given to Brexit scrutiny. Despite this Mr Hoyle is generally regarded as a popular figure who hasnapost made enemies in the same way as Bercow. And he’s been widely complimented for his approach to handling Budget debates, which has been part of his job as Chairman of Ways and Means. He was in the Speaker’s chair at the time of the Westminster Terror Attack of  March  - and the subsequent lockdown of the Houses of Parliament.    There was an outpouring of tributes in  when his -year-old daughter Natalie was found dead. An inquest recorded an open verdict, but heard she was involved in a “toxic” relationship before her death. Speaking in the Commons last year, her MP John Whittingdale said: At the end of last year my constituent Natalie Lewis-Hoyle, the daughter of Councillor Miriam Lewis and our right honourable friend the member for Chorley took her own le having been in a coercive relationship and suffered mental abuse in what is known as gaslighting. He called for more awareness of this kind of abuse in which a perpetrator tries to sow seeds of doubt in their victim so they begin to doubt their own sanity. And he asked then-Prime Minister Theresa May to support ‘Chat with Nat’, a charity set up by Natalieaposs mum to help other victims who feel they have no where to turn.

I found out that it was operable and that there were quite high survival rates. But on October , Michelle and Joe received some crushing news. Their soon to be born baby had such a severe case of HLHS that the doctoraposs wouldnapost be able to operate. Despite the news, Michelle was keen to push ahead, giving birth to Harry at .am on October . She said: Itaposs so hard. title: hero teacher tried save pupil
story: NewsSchoolgirl drowned on Drayton Manor school trip after going on ride without teacherEvha Jannath stood up on the Splash Canyon ride at the Staffordshire theme park and was thrown into the waterShareByMartin Fricker:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsEvha Jannath died after falling from the Splash Canyon ride at Drayton Manor "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA schoolgirl drowned at a popular theme park after plunging from a water ride while messing around with classmates, an inquest heard. Tragic Evha Jannath, , died when she fell from the Splash Canyon ride during a trip to Drayton Manor in Staffordshire. She had been allowed to go on a raft with four primary-age classmates without a teacher when the tragedy happened in May . CCTV footage showed Evha standing up in the six-seater vessel and being thrown into the water moments from the end of the ride. She survived the fall and began wading through thigh-deep water towards a “travelator” carrying the raft to the exit.    But Evha then suddenly disappeared from view and was found by park staff lying face-down in a ft-deep pool next to the ride. Stafford County Hall was told she was airlted to Birmingham Children’s Hospital but died later the same day. Evha and her classmates had obeyed the rules to remain seated during an earlier turn on the ride while accompanied by a teacher. But jurors were told several of the girls flouted the rules on the second trip - when there were no adults in the raft. The inquest was told the youngsters, from the private Jame’ah Girls Academy in Leicester, wanted to see who could “get the wettest”. Giving evidence Det Insp John Quilty, of Staffordshire Police, said Evha did not sit on a seat at any point on the ride. “They were reaching out of the vessel, putting their hands in the water during the ride,” he said. “One girl said they were talking about who could get the wettest. They were having fun but sadly we now know the consequences of this.”  The inquest heard she stood up at the “worst possible moment” and fell head-first into the water as her classmates screamed in horror. Jurors were told the youngster, who was wearing a white headscarf and hooded jacket, could not swim. One of Evha’s classmates who was on the boat told police: “Evha was not sitting on the seat. She was on the step and fell off. “She was in the water, holding something. We told her to get on another boat but she could not. “We asked the other boatsthey had seen our Evha but they had not.” Another child on the boat said: “When we were near the end a big tide came and Evha fell in. “We told her to climb in a boat but we think she could not hear us.” A third girl said: “The others were talking about how badly they wanted to get wet.
