title: pumpkin-patch-nursery-boss-admits-defeat-closing-dunbar-nursery
story: Jonathan Bruneau said the Dunbar branch of his Pumpkin Patch Nurseries would close permanently in two weeks after  years of looking after children in the town.The nursery was criticised in a recent Care Inspectorate report over changing staff and a lack of management.However, Mr Bruneau, who also has Pumpkin Patch nurseries in North Berwick and Haddington, said the problems had been created by Scottish Government demands.He said: ldquoUnfortunately we have had to admit defeat related to our ability to staff and manage our Dunbar setting.ldquoRecruiting management and senior staff has been impossible over recent years due to Scottish Government policies which have driven the average age and experience of nursery practitioners down to levels which are simply not appropriate to run a nursery.ldquoNursery staff work long hours for salaries which are not commensurate with the level of education and expertise they are expected to achieve.ldquoThis, plus the rolling out of , hours per year of free nursery care , has created a staffing crisis most noticeably felt in rural areas where staff cannot afford to travel from Edinburgh or beyond.ldquoThe final straw came when we lost our most recent manager after three months when she was poached by a nursery closer to home. This was inevitable as she had been travelling one hour each way to get to Dunbar and, even though subsidised by us to make the journey, a two-hour commute is simply not sustainable.Mr Bruneau warned of the impact of demands on private nurseries in April this year when his nursery in Haddington saw its grades fall in an inspection. He said: ldquoThis is a systematic problem which is causing a death spiral in the quality of nursery provision throughout the industry.The inspection report on Dunbarrsquos Pumpkin Patch rated its quality of care and support, staffing and management and leadership at twowith the environment rated a three .The report said that parents had contacted the inspectorate following its unannounced visit in August to discuss concerns.A high turnover in staff was raised by a number of parents, with one telling inspectors: ldquoOften when I drop my child off I have to introduce myself and my child to the agency staff.The report said: ldquoParents told us that they often did not know the staff when they dropped off their children in the morning, often resulting in their children being reluctant to attend.Mr Bruneau said that the introduction of mandatory SSSCregistration was creating recruitment problems throughout the industry.He said: ldquoBefore the advent of SSSC registration, our group of nurseries never used any agency staff as recruitment was simple. It included people of ying ages, experience and circumstance.ldquoIt was a healthy labour market now new staff are iniably under , inexperienced in le, work and certainly the care of children.ldquoNursery closures are inevitable as sites struggle to find staff, maintain standards and satisfy increased demand.He said his company had decided to rationalise itsservices, placing more experience in fewer sites, and called on the Scottish Government to reverse policies he said ruled out more mature staff from working in nurseries.He added that all five members of staff at Dunbar had been offered places at his other nurseries.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council, which used the Dunbar nursery as a partner provider, said: ldquoWe have worked with Pumpkin Patch as one of our partner providers, offering funded early learning and childcare for pre-school children for many years.ldquoOur officers have also provided extensive support to the Dunbar team to help them improve the quality of experiences following recent Care Inspectorate reports. Our assistance has been recognised and appreciated by the owners, who feel that we have done all we can to support them.ldquoWe acknowledge that this will have been a dficult decision for the owners and will have implications for their team at Dunbar. We also acknowledge the upset and disruption that the nursery closure will bring for parents using this service.ldquoOur staff will work with and support parents to find alternative early learning and childcare within the area that meets their needs.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoMore than , children are already benefiting from the expanded entitlement after we increased training opportunities and routes into the early learning and childcare sector, resulting in a record ,-strong workforce.ldquoWe are working alongside local authorities and providers to ensure the necessary workforce is in place ndash including running a national early learning and childcare recruitment campaign, increasing support for training places and modern apprenticeships, and enabling providers to advertise jobs free on the MyJobScotland website.

title: pensioner-completes-74-year-quest-discover-father
story: David Simpson had spent  years looking for his dad after growing up in a Quarriers orphanage to the west of Glasgow before moving across the Atlantic.But his attempts proved fruitless until a visit to long-lost family in Elgin last year.John Hamilton, from Lost Haddington, then became aware of Mr Simpsonrsquos quest.He said: ldquoFrom the information David received from Quarriers, all he knew was that his father was a Jack Cunningham, a plasterer from Goodallrsquos Place in Haddington.ldquoHis niece AnnMarie Whyte did a search for Goodallrsquos Place and the result came back with a find against a Lost Haddington image for the old Goodallrsquos shop on the townrsquos Bridge Street this led to AnnMarie posting a question askingI knew who Jack Cunningham was.ldquoA search of the Lost Haddington collection for Cunningham brought back too many matches, so the search was honed to lsquoplastererrsquo and the results produced the equivalent of a Holy Grail image ndash a George Angus scan of a lsquoJohnrsquo Cunninghamrsquos security application to RAF East Fortune.As well as correcting the name, the image confirmed his occupation and address, as well as his height, hair and eye colour.A plea was put on social media for further information, which found that Johnrsquos nickname was lsquoGibbyrsquo and that David had a cousin living in Musselburgh called Janette Brotherstone.Mr Hamilton said: ldquoAlso, a further search of Lost Haddington for the word lsquoGibbyrsquo, with it being an unusual name, produced another George Angus image from  showing Davidrsquos father John when he was only five or six years old holding the date plate for his school photo ndash George had annotated the image saying the lsquoboy holding the date slate was Gibby Cunninghamrsquo, so when I sent David this image it was the first time hersquod seen his father.ldquoThe feedback from the Lost Haddington followers also indicated that John died in  when he lived at No  St Annrsquos Place.ldquoThrough the invaluable feedback which named Janette as his first cousin, David was put in touch with her and shersquos since sent him some old family photos showing his father throughout his le.ldquoThe photos came from Davidrsquos fatherrsquos home, where he died, as it was Janette who dealt with the death notices for both Davidrsquos father and Johnrsquos we Jessie Cagder.ldquoDavid visited Scotland in autumn  so I offered to bring him to Haddington, which he accepted.From there, David, who now lives in Rochester, New York, was able to see the home where his dad was born on Haddingtonrsquos St Martinrsquos Gate, as well as his homes on Goodallrsquos Place and St Annrsquos Place.It is thought Davidrsquos dad was lodged with a landlady while working in Elgin in .According to Mr Hamilton: ldquoThe landladyrsquos husband was away from home for two years as a soldier in World War Two and itrsquos during this period that John and the landlady must have had a moment of indiscretion together, which produced David!ldquoWhen the landladyrsquos husband ed home from the war due to injury and found his we holding baby David ndash that couldnrsquot have been his ndash he gave his we the ultimatum: lsquoTake him to the orphanage or itrsquos a orce.rsquoldquoAt the age of around one month old, David was taken to the Quarriers orphanage which is near the Bridge of Weir to the west of Glasgow.David left Quarriers at the age of  and eventually moved to Winnipeg in Canada in  before eventually settling in New York.More than  years ago, he began his bid to track down his family. That saw him told that his dad had lodged with the Simpson family in Elgin.David then wrote to all the Simpsons he could find in Elgin, which saw him eventually meet two half-brothers and two half-sisters before the breakthrough with the Haddington connection.

title: josh-taylors-girlfriend-says-boxing-star-dedicating-world-title-win-late-dad-means-world-me
story: Josh, from Prestonpans, beat American Regis Prograis in the final of the World Boxing Super Series at super lightweight at Londonrsquos O Arena on Saturday.Speaking from the ring, he dedicated his win to Daniellersquos dad James Murphy, also from Prestonpans, who died on September  at the age of .Josh said: ldquoI want to dedicate this fight to my father-in-law, who passed away on September . Jimmy, this is for you.Danielle told the Courier the dedication meant the world to her and said her dad would have been thrilled.James Murphy was a joiner who lived on South Grange Avenue, Prestonpans, with his we of  years Lorraine and their -year-old son Connor.Josh chose Jamesrsquo favourite song to be his ringwalk music on Saturday: Step On by the Happy Mondays.Danielle told the Courier: ldquoIt just means the world to me that Josh dedicated his win to my dad.ldquoHe [my dad] would have been cheesing about it.ldquoItrsquos been a really hard time just now. title: school-pupils-tranent-come-together-climate-conversation
story: A Big Climate Conversation was held in St Martinrsquos Church Hall last Friday.School pupils were the main organisers of the event, marketed as: ldquoWhat the hell do the kids in Tranent know about climate change The community was welcomed to share their views on how Scotland can respond to the global climate emergency and feedback will be provided to the Scottish Government.The interactive conversation was led by children and featured games and music encouraging the people of Tranent to think about climate change as a human rights issue which must be addressed.The children in charge made sure the event was as carbon neutral as possible and even rented reusable plastic plates from Lower Impact Living, East Saltoun, to serve food on.At the end of the event, they had participants make pledges about what they were personally going to do to help tackle climate change.The event was organised by volunteers from Ross High School, Pencaitland Primary School, St Martinrsquos Eco Group, Farsquoside Womenrsquos Group and the Childrenrsquos Parliament and was sponsored by the Scottish Governmentrsquos The Big Climate Conversation Community Fund.Amy Gossner, , from Ross High School, was one of the youngsters key in organising the event and said: ldquoWe want everyone to be more aware of climate change.ldquoI think a lot of people donrsquot realise how much climate change is going to impact everyone in the future.ldquoItrsquos not just happening on TV, itrsquos happening everywhere in the world and itrsquos everyonersquos responsibility.ldquoOur aim is to find out what people in the community, especially children, think is the way forward and what they think other people can do to help prevent climate change.Claire MacGillivray, a Trustee of the Childrenrsquos Parliament, said: ldquoOn the back of this event, we will be sending a report to the Scottish Government but I think itrsquos really about starting the conversation.We have a reason to make the world a better place: for our children. They are taking the lead by showing adults that they want things to change.Paul Reynolds, headteacher at Ross High School, said: ldquoI am delighted that our pupils are proactively seeking to raise awareness of these issues and look at ways to make positive changes.ldquoWe also have a group looking at ways to highlight this important issue in school so this is clearly an issue which means a lot to our pupils.The Big Climate Conversation Community Fund was launched in August to assist community organisations to host workshops and engage in the climate change debate. It is managed by Impact Funding on behalf of the Scottish Government.Sixty-two groups have been approved to receive funding so far which project to engage more than , members of the public in the climate conversation.

title: liberal-democrats-formally-adopt-general-election-candidate-east-lothian
story: The Lib Dems had been the first party to select a General Election candidate in the county, announcing back in March that the partys East Lothian convenor Robert ORiordan would be their prospective candidate in the anticipation of an election being held in the near future.Now that a General Election has been formally announced for December , the Lib Dems formally adopted Mr ORiordan as their candidate for East Lothian at a meeting in Haddington.Mr OrsquoRiordan has lived in Gullane since . This resonates with voters throughout East Lothian."Voters are fed up with isive politics and want governments at Westminster and Holyrood to get back to their proper job ndash tackling urgent and pressing environmental, social and economic challenges. Parties need to work with each other and not against each other to achieve this."Mending our broken politics, including constitutional reform and the introduction of proportional representation at Westminster, are top of my shopping list.In next months poll, Mr ORiordan is up against sitting MP Martin Whitfield , former Justice Secretary Kenny MacAskilland Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillor Craig Hoy .Nominations for the election close at pm next Thursday .In the last election in , Mr Whitfield pulled in , votes to beat the SNPs George Kerevan , who finished narrowly ahead of Sheila Low of the Conservatives . story: Tchai-OvnaHidden down a wee cobbled lane in the heart of Glasgowrsquos West End, on entering Tchai-Ovna you would be forgiven for thinking you are stepping into a Himalayan tea room or a Turkish bazar.Tchai-Ovna was founded in  by a group of Glasgow University students tired of the prevalent alcohol culture. Too young to get business funding, with help from friends and the community they invested their student loans and refurbished the premises, keeping as many original features as possible: cobbled floors, horsersquos tethers etc. The vegetarian speciality tea house they created was only supposed to last a year, but almost twenty years on it is now a firmly established Glasgow institution."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Tchai-Ovna","description": "Tchai-Ovna","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media dSMDgrx poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests dSMDgrx.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Today the menu represents a broad swathe of cultures including Mexican, Arabic and Indian. Whilst you are enjoying your meal you can partake in one of around  speciality teas, all Tchai-Ovna own brand, and many of them blended in house and to order. They also retail many of the teas in the shop and online as well as wholesale across Scotland.Many know Tchai-Ovna as a much loved community hub, where people of all ages and backgrounds meet to socialise, play board games and listen to local, and international, live music acts and performances. It is welcoming, informal and unpretentious. Perhaps it is for this reason that even well-known celebs have become patrons. Belle and Sebastienrsquos album art for Dear Catastrophe Waitress was shot here, members of Franz Ferdinand stop by when they are not on tour, and Scarlett Johansson likes it so much she has been twice.Whatever your reason, be sure to stop by for a cuppa when you are in Glasgow.www.tchaiovna Otago LaneGlasgowG PBOpen am-pm every day----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Hanoi Bike ShopVietnamese food was vegan friendly before vegans were vegan. The streets of Hanoi are filled with vegetables and fresh produce that many of us here in Scotland have never heard of, let alone tasted. Plant-based food is everywhere in Vietnam and at the Hanoi Bike Shop they continue this tradition without ever sacricing taste or flavour.The little restaurant is situation just off Byres Road in the West End. The twinkly lights, Vietnamese flags and vintage bikes will draw you down the lane but once you get through the door donrsquot be put by the smell, they swear itrsquos not lsquowet dogrsquo or lsquohamster cagesrsquo as some TripAdvisor reviews would have you think. Fish sauce is a staple in Vietnamese cuisine and does leave a lasting impression on the senses. Although they use Tamariin all of their vegan dishes the fresh pho broths are always on the boil and help to give Hanoi its distinctive odour.Hanoi Bike Shop chefs have created a vegan menu influenced by seasonal availability of local produce as well as the salty, sweet, sour and spicy balance of Vietnamese cuisine.The star of course, is their organic handmade tofu, which is carefully, simmered, strained and pressed daily in house.Hanoirsquos vegan menu consists of over twenty freshly prepared dishes ranging from Kimchi Spring Rolls and Daikon and Soya Bean Cakes to Chilli Glazed Sesame Rice Cakes and Curried Banana.They implore all customers to adopt their dining motto lsquosharing is caringrsquo and go for the lsquoFeed Mersquo option. Then you just sit back, relax and let the banquet begin.www.hanoibikeshopInstagram www.instagram hanoibikeshop Facebook www.facebook TheHanoiBikeShop booking.resdiary widget Standard HanoiBikeShop  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------OM Sweet OMOM Sweet OM is a vibrant haven, tucked behind Central Station in Oswald St, in the centre of Glasgow, committed to the art of sustainable happiness and conscious living. This is aimed at homeless people and also promote plant-based diets."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "OM Sweet OM","description": "OM Sweet OM","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media PfqkSp poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests PfqkSp.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Just as the body needs nourishment by vegan superfood, they also offer yoga classes to maintain a good flow of healthy energy. title: If Labour win  it  39 ll be less like Venezuela than Britain circa 1974
story: Jeremy Corbyn was also talking tough this week. He identied some of the capitalist criminals Labour is coming for, including Sir Jim Ratclfe of Ineos. Though itrsquos not clear under what law the polluting plutocrats could be prosecuted.So, is this class war in the UK  Are we on the road to Venezuela  Whatever the polls say, a Labour victory this Christmas is quite possible with Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party now splitting the Tory vote. There is a powerful mood for change in Britain. But what would a Labour government actually look like We have never had such an avowedly radical Prime Minister ndash not even in , when Labour was led by a small ldquoc conservative, Clement Attlee. However, Labour reality would be rather dferent from the rhetoric. Burrow into Labourrsquos policies, and what emerges looks more like reheated social democracy, circa, than a Bolshevik revolution.For a start, we can largely ignore the issue that ided the party so bitterly in recent times: nuclear weapons. Jeremy Corbyn may be a lelong member of CND, but Labour is no longer a unilateralist party. Its  manesto committed a Labour government to renewing Trident almost indefinitely.But Corbyn will still enter Number  with a raft of left-wing policies, from seizing corporate assets to abolishing private schools as well as taxing the rich until the pips squeak. However, many of the headline policies will never make it to first reading, let alone the statute book.Abolishing schools like Eton would involve y court action, not least from faith schools and the home school movement, who might also be affected. Labour is more likely to confine its assault on educational privilege to axeing tax reliefs worth about pound. billionSimilarly, seizing % of the shares of companies with more than  employees would be fiercely resisted in the courts by shareholders. They have deep pockets. I suspect Labour would confine itself to increasing corporate taxes, ending zero-hours contracts and restoring trades union rights ndash all of which are eminently doable.Indeed, looking behind the radical rhetoric, much of Labourrsquos policy agenda is surprisingly modest, viewed from Scotland. Measures like free personal care, abolishing university tuition fees, childcare for three and four-year-olds, scrapping the right to buy, lting the benefits cap and the bedroom tax ndash these are all achievable.Indeed, the Scottish Parliament has already achieved them, bar the welfare cap. Nicola Sturgeon will no doubt remind the Labour leader of this repeatedly in coming weeks.Nationalisation is a policy that used to be seen as ldquoloony left but is no longer. Taking rail into public ownership shouldnrsquot be too much of a problem, since Network Rail, which owns the track and signalling, is already in public hands. The service franchises could be replaced as they come up for renewal, without needing to hand billions in compensation to Virgin and the rest.Waterand energy would pose greater problems, not least because most of our energy companies are foreign-owned ndash often, ironically, by state-owned bodies. But with a good wind it should be possible for Labour to find a way. Public attitudes to public ownership of utilities have changed out of all recognition since the s.Similarly, there is broad public support for Labourrsquos Green New Deal. A majority of voters agrees there is a climate emergency. Though they may not agree with the measures needed to tackle it.Labour is not going the full Extinction Rebellion route of making Britain zero carbon by . But its own policy, passed at conference, is still pretty radical. It commits a Labour government to making Britain zero carbon by . Thatrsquos only five years longer.We are talking about the most radical change to our lestyles since the industrial revolution. Labourrsquos policy would mean decarbonising transport, home heating and agriculture in a decade. Millions of cars would have to be scrapped along with millions of home boilers. Air travel would all but cease.Labour promises a huge investment in renewable industries to compensate, but that is unlikely to replace the jobs lost in the car industry, oil and gas, road haulage and retail.So expect the Green New Deal to become somewhat lighter green in government. There is likely to be a rt between the Thunberg-supporting ldquode-growthers and Labour MPs, who traditionally see economic growth as the best way to address poverty and inequality.However, Britain already has a rather good record on eliminating greenhouse emissions, and this will continue, albeit with the  target reduced to % net zero.In sum, Labour offers a practical social democratic programme which could be very attractive to voters, especially younger ones. However there is one very big problem: Brexit.Labour is committed to negotiating a new Withdrawal Deal to replace Boris Johnsonrsquosand to putting this to another Brexit referendum. This will consume a vast amount of political capital and will surely dominate the first year of a Labour government.Corbyn wants to reintroduce the customs union and Brussels would probably agree to that. But Labour also wants close regulatory alignment with the European Single Market, which the EU  would probably reject. If Britain wants to be in the single market, it will have to join the single market, probably via the European Economic Area, along with Norway.Labour could go along with that in the end, since it wants friction-free access to the EU markets. Single market membership would solve the Irish border problem, for sure.But it would also mean Britain continuing to contribute to the EU Budget, while having no say over decisions taken by Brussels. Customs union membership requires oversight by the European Court of Justice, which will displease many.But that wouldnrsquot be the main problem. If Labour got this wonderful deal, including workersrsquo rights and environmental standards, and got it through Parliament , would it really then campaign against it in the confirmatory referendum Interviewers have largely stopped asking this question, because they never get an answer, but Europe remains a huge question mark hanging over Labourrsquos government agenda.Labour is still a Brexit party, though you wouldnrsquot know it to listen to most MPs. Many figures in the party are closet Brexiteers, like Jeremy Corbyn himself. Others are openly pro-Brexit, like the party chairman Ian Lavery and the MPs who voted for Boris Johnsonrsquos deal.Equally dedicated Remainers ndash mostly Blairites and supporters of the deputy leader Tom Watson ndash would fight back, insisting that Labour effectively promised to back Remain in the General Election. Brexit wrangling could delay the confirmatory referendum and ide the party, just as it split the Tories.Corbynrsquos enemies will ignite further ision by condemning him as anti-Semitic. It will take immense powers of leadership to prevent a Labour government being halted in its radical tracks by Brexit.The question for voters is: does Jeremy Corbyn possess it

title: 70-000-trees-take-root-scottish-schools
story: East Lothian nursery Alba Trees, is providing a range of packs to suit dferent needs on behalf of the Woodland Trust on a first come first served basis to any groups that will use them to help green public spaces.Nearly , schools and other groups will receive , saplings this month, thanks to the initiative which is funded by Sainsburyrsquos, Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery, Yorkshire Tea and Selfridges.In Scotland alone, , trees are being sent out to  dferent organisations.Woodland Trust Scotland Director Carol Evans said tree planting had never been higher on the social and political agenda, amid increasing public awareness that we are in a climate crisis.ldquoPeople are waking up to the message that trees are a big part of the solution to tackling climate change, she said.ldquoWe need more of them so it is fantastic that we are able to provide these free trees for schools and communities across the country.Woodland Trustsrsquos Big Climate Fightback aims to get more than a million people to pledge to plant a tree on the run up to a mass day of planting across the UK on November .ldquoReducing our carbon emissions will never be enough. Itrsquos vital we grow a UK-wide patchwork of trees and woods - not just by planting, but also through natural regeneration, the campaign says. ldquoThe woods, hedges and green spaces we create buffer existing habitats, tackle climate change and reverse wildle decline ndash all at the same time.Groups are also being invited to apply for a free tree pack as part of the next round of deliveries which will be sent out in March , with organisations that apply getting added to a list of trustees.As well as schools ndash which must plant the trees on the school grounds ndash community groups are eligible so long as the trees are planted on land which is publicly accessible.Applicants must provide a grid reference for the land they wish to plant on, and also secure the permission of the landownernecessary or demonstrate local community support.The packs will be allocated until they run out, but those applying will need sufficient space: the smallest packs are for restricted urban spaces but still include  trees, while larger packs contain up to  trees ndash enough to fill a football pitch.Depending on a grouprsquos requirements, would-be planters can choose from eight dferent categories of pack.The Hedge pack contains  trees, a mix of dog rose, hawthorn, hazel, crab apple and dogwood, enough for eight metres of lsquoeasy to managersquo hedging. Copse contains enough saplings to plant a ldquosmall tranquil copse that is an oasis for birds, including silver birch, rowan and wild cherry.Wild Harvest includes species such as hazel, blackthorn, crab apple and elder, which will produce an array of fruits and nuts suitable for preserving as jams, jellies, wines or cordials, while the lsquoYear Round Colourrsquo pack promises beautul blossoms, bright berries stunning shades in the autumn and includes wild cherry and dogwood.The industrious can order a Working Wood pack which will provide logs for fuel in - years or materials for crafts such as carving and willow weaving. This pack includes common oak, field maple and grey willow. Groups seeking something less domesticated, or those with exposed sites or boggy ground can request a Wild Wood pack, which includes hawthorn, holly, downy birch and goat willow.The popular Wildle pack aims to provide both food and shelter for beasts large and small, and includes a mix of traditional species such as hawthorn, blackthorn and silver birch. Finally the Urban Trees pack - which is designed for residential areas with limited communal space - offers a mixture of  saplings from three species, crab apple, rowan and hazel , all well-equipped to thrive in urban settings.All the trees are sourced in the UK and grown under the Trustrsquos quality assurance scheme guaranteeing the provenance of native trees.Launched last year the UKSGguarantees that trees awarded the badge are raised from seeds sourced only from the UK and grown in the UK for their entire lespan.The aim is to reduce the risk of importing pests and diseases with planting stock grown outside the UK. Groups wishing to apply can visit www.woodlandtrust.org.uk freetrees.Established in , the Woodland Trust aims to protect and restore ancient woodland while planting native trees to create ldquoresilient woods benefitting both people and wildle.

story: The -year-old Labour politician, who was knighted in  for parliamentary and political services, also clashed with former Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond during a Brexit debate in February .Mr Salmond accused the Deputy Speaker of cutting off SNP MP Joanna Cherry while she was speaking and the row escalated as Mr Hoyle shouted that Mr Salmond ldquoshould know better and ordered him to ldquosit down. Tempers were rising after seven hours of debate as the Brexit Bill that would trigger Article  reached committee stage in the Commons.:Sir Lindsay Hoyle elected new speaker of the House of CommonsThe row occurred after the Mr Salmond raised a point of order saying: "It is quite clear that the honourable member had not resumed her seat, Sir. Being in the chair accords you many privileges but you cannot reinterpret the wishes of an honourable member who is on her feet."Mr Hoyle responded: "As the chair I have the right to make decisions on this House. What I would say is quite rightly when I wanted to bring her in [Joanna Cherry MP], which I did ... I certainly dont expect advantages to be taken of the chair on the agreements that I make."Referring to the Brexit Bill, he said: "It is a very serious matter, it is so serious that I want to hear what the minister has to say."Mr Hoyle has been widely complimented for his approach to handling Budget debates, which has been part of his job as chairman of Ways and Means.:Sir Lindsay Hoyle elected new speaker of the House of CommonsHe taught his pet parrot Boris to shout ldquoorder order! and named his tortoise Maggie, after the late Tory Prime Minister because she had a hard shell and was "not for turning".The Lancashire-born businessman was one of just three Labour MPs who did not declare their voting intention in the  EU referendum. His Lancashire district backed Brexit by % to %.He vowed to "tame the bear pit" of a "toxic Parliament"elected to the role of Speaker, sayinghe would crack down on aggressive language.He went to private Lords College in Bolton and ran his own screen-printing firm before becoming an MP in .The seasonedpolitician was elected as Deputy Speaker of the House in a secret ballot on June .He was in the Speakerrsquos chair at the time of the Westminster Terror Attack of  March  - and the subsequent lockdown of the Houses of Parliament.After winning the final round of voting on Monday against Chris Bryant, Sir Lindsay was dragged to the chair by MPs, where he pledged to be a "neutral" Speaker.He also paid tribute to his daughter, Natalie, who died in , saying she would "always be missed".

title: footballs-really-coming-home-plans-restoration-original-hampden-site-unveiled-tennents
story: But now, the location of the worldrsquos first purpose-built international football ground is set to be properly recognised for the first time.Hampden Bowling Club is long suspected to be the site of Scotlandrsquos original national stadium - playing host to our - thrashing of England in .However, the rich history of the former stadium - which also played host to the pioneering Queenrsquos Park side of the late th century - has long been lost since the majority of the structure which stood on the site was dismantled in the rsquos to make way for a railway line.:Club mural marks the lsquolostrsquo home of footballNow, brewer Tennentrsquos has unveiled new plans to ldquorestore, repair and celebrate the legacy of Scotlandrsquos first footballing home thanks to a five-figure investment which will see parts of the bowling club pavillion that retain the features of the original faithfully revived.James Hughes, Tennentrsquos brand manager, said: ldquoWersquore in no doubt about the signicance Hampden Bowling Club has in world football. Tennentrsquos is as synonymous with the game in Scotland as the Hampden Roar and the half-time pie.ldquoWersquore thrilled to continue our long and proud association with Scottish football and to be able to play our part in preserving the most important site in the history of the worldrsquos favourite sport - just a couple of miles from the site of one of Scotlandrsquos oldest breweries.He added: ldquoHugh Tennent was a man who loved to engage with his cityrsquos culture in the late s, and wersquore confident Hugh would have been at the first Hampden Park cheering on Scotland in their triumphs in the early days of Tennentrsquos Lager.Under the proposals, the roof, windows and electrics within the pavilion will be completely repaired, with the outside grounds - which contain a mural celebrating Scotlandrsquos win over the Auld Enemy and a tribute to Andrew Watson, believed to be the first black player in association football - also improved.A lsquoTennentrsquos Redrsquo plaque has been unveiled at the site - thought to have given birth to the version of the game as it is now known the world over.The Hampden Collection - a group committed to promoting the legacy of the Three Hampdens - claim the venue is home to the ldquomodern lsquopass and moversquo style of football, believed to have been invented by Scottish clans more than  years ago.It was later passed down through the generations in northern Scotland, with the Highlandersrsquo influence shaping the game when many of them moved south to Glasgow and formed Queenrsquos Park in .The attractive style of play was later adopted around the world, influencing the great Brazil side of , the Dutch interpretation of lsquoTotal Footballrsquo and Barcelonarsquos lsquotiki-takarsquo of the modern era.The stadium hosted the first ever Scottish Cup final, a - win for The Spiders against Clydesdale in  as well as several early Scotland international matches.The second Hampden Park opened in  and later became known as lsquoCathkin Park,rsquo while the current site came into use in October .Scottish Football Museum creator Ged OrsquoBrien said: ldquoThe line in the song lsquofootballrsquos coming homersquo is simply not correct.: The Five Greatest Scotland Football TeamsldquoThe true home of the passing and running game is what we know now as Hampden Bowling Club. This style of contest was so popular and successful that it was exported from Scotland all over the world.He added: ldquoIt became the way the game was played around the world, and we have evidence to the fact that it was officially established here in Glasgow.The Hampden Collection have promoted the refurbishment of the site on social media, using the hashtag #RestorestHampden.Graeme Brown, Co-Founder of the Hampden Collection, said: ldquoAs wersquove seen at all three Hampden venues over the years, great teams can do great things.""Wersquore delighted to have teamed up with Tennentrsquos to kick-off our drive to #RestorestHampden and ensure it becomes an essential part of Scottish History for future generations to enjoy.

title: pm-cover-claim-blocked-russian-vote-interference-report
story: It has gone through the standard security clearance process, but Downing Street indicated that it would not allow the potentially incendiary -page dossier from the intelligence and security committee to be published immediately.The report was expected to include evidence rom UK intelligence services over covert Russian attempts to influence the outcome of the  EU referendum and  general election.Ex-terrorism watchdog Lord Anderson said any further delay would "invite suspicion" of the governments motives in the run-up to next months election.: Issue of the Day -Fears over electoral interference by RussiaThe committeersquos chairman, Dominic Grieve, called the decision ldquojaw dropping, saying no reason for the refusal had been given, while Labour and Scottish Nationalist party politicians accused No  of refusing to recognise the scale of Russian meddling.Ministers said the report, which examines Russian activity including allegations of espionage, subversion and interference in elections, would be published "in due course" in line with procedures for "sensitive" information.The report, written by Parliaments Intelligence and Security Committee, was finalised in March and referred to No  on October .The usual -day wait for release has passed, andit is not published before Parliament dissolves on Tuesday it will not be published ahead of the election.A No  spokesman added: ldquoThere are processes reports such as this have to go through before publication, and the committee is well-informed of these.Mr Grieve said ldquoThe protocols are quite clear. If the prime minister has a good reason for preventing publication he should explain to the committee what it is, and do it within  days of him receiving the report. If not, it should be published.He added: "We continue to be very disappointed by the failure of the government to publish this report and to provide any explanation as to why it should not be published. Explanations currently advanced that the timing are too short are entirely disingenuous and grossly misleading."Joined my colleague David Anderson in pressing Govt on failure to publish this report. I stressed the public interest in knowing the security implications of Russiarsquos adversarial behaviour. Also that the ISC is the only Select Cttee that needs Govt OK to publish. title: vintage-couple-take-diners-back-time-1940s-tearoom
story: The walls are decorated with posters of rock-and-roll stars Elvis Presley and Gene Vincent. A radio on an art deco mantle plays oldies from the s.Samantha, whose pin-curled hair is fastened with a pink flower to match her ankle- skirt, bakes every kind of homemade goodie from Victorian sponge cakes to fresh scones.Visitors wonrsquot find internet for their electronics, but they will regularly see patrons, from elderly couples enjoying tea to busy students working on assignments. That is because the dated tile floors and mismatched vintage furniture isnrsquot inside the Newellrsquos home ndash itrsquos their family business nestled cozily in an upstairs apartment on Ashton Lane.ldquoI want this to take them back to grandmarsquos house, Samantha said. ldquoWhen serving people things, I donrsquot do dainty. I give what I would like to have myself, soI serve a piece of cakehellip itrsquos going to be a whole piece of cake.:Cake critic -The Cup and Saucer Vintage Tearoom, GlasgowThe Cup and Saucer Vintage Tea Room was born out of the couplersquos love for all things vintage. When Tony was  years old, he came across a Gene Vincent record, and since then began styling himself as a teddy boy, complete with a greased quf hairdo and tight jeans. ldquoBack then when I used to wear my leather jacket old ladies would walk across the road to avoid me, Tony said. ldquoBut in Glasgow no-one bats an eye. Most people react with a smile.While it took several years for the tearoom to become the local staple it is today, the Newellrsquos partnership was love at first sight. The couple met on a school bus in  when they were  years old and married five years later. Samantha said she was initially into the hard rock of the s and s, but Tonyrsquos passion for vintage slowly changed her aestheticism. She began by making her own circle skirts, and now exclusively wears vintage clothing like her husband.Samantha said dressing in vintage makes her feel classy and smart like she is part of an era where people cared about style and how they were presented. Sometimes patrons think the couplersquos dress is a unorm, and that they go home and put on lsquonormal clothesrsquo at the end of the day.ldquoItrsquos like a kind of unorm but itrsquos not, Samantha said. ldquoItrsquos just us. Itrsquos not for the tearoom. Itrsquos us every day.The business began when Samantha wanted to share her baking with the community. She initially ran it alone with Tony and their two children helping on weekends. When Tony concluded his service in the Royal Navy after a -year career, he came to work full-time.Most of the furniture comes from their home, as they try to live as authentic a vintage lestyle they can. Any electronics they do use such as a microwave and CD player are hidden in cabinets. Some items are also donated by regulars to the cafeacute, such as a cabinet from a grandmotherrsquos garage that now holds old saucers. Samantha says when someone donates cups or plates, she tries her best to serve them with it when they come to eat.The Cup and Saucer is coming upon its eight-year anniversary, and the couple says its mission still stands: to give people living in the busy city of Glasgow a place to relax. Their advertisement is exclusively by word-of-mouth, and they are proud that the tearoom is not on the main street.Tony said they donrsquot want to put more tables in so people are sat on top of each other because it would ruin the homey feel. However, even with no advertisement there is still a queue to get in on weekends, which he said is a testament to his wersquos baking.Leslie Watson, a woman in her s ing to school to study climate justice, has become a regular patron to the Cup and Saucer because of its relaxing atmosphere.ldquoI feel like Irsquom at my grandparentsrsquo house like everythingrsquos okay in the world, Watson said.The couple ndash who call each other their best friend ndash have no plans to change the shop anytime soon. In their spare time Samantha said she has dreams to be on the British Bake Off, and Tony DJs local rockabilly shows as DJ Sailor Tony.Both say that they arenrsquot trying to be pretentious by their vintage lestyle, but that they want to create a little home in Glasgow for those who need it.ldquoWe hope that they leave full of the happy memories that wersquove taken them back to, Samantha said.

title: neil-mackay-question-time-comes-scotland-week---must-stop-destruction-trust
story: During the last edition of the political  show the broadcaster allowed lies and disinformation to go out over the airwaves uncorrected, infecting public discourse.An audience member told the  that the Vote Leave campaign had broken electoral law, and said Dominic Cummings, the Prime Ministerrsquos special adviser, had refused to come before parliament.Presenter Fiona Bruce told the young woman: ldquoIrsquom not entirely sure yoursquore right about that. Bruce also appeared to confuse Vote Leave with the Leave.EU campaign.The young woman defended her position, but was told by Bruce ldquono criminal charges were brought.The right-wing journalist Isabel Oakeshott, who was a list, then jumped in to say: ldquoThe vast majority of allegations about both Leave campaigns were found to be completely untrue. This was propaganda.The audience member was correct, however ndash Vote Leave broke the law. Yet, any viewer would have left the programme believing the opposite.This is a critical failure by the BBC. The national broadcaster is meant to provide unbiased, accurate reporting. It did the opposite on Question Time.This General Election is one that will be fought on lies, deceit and manipulation. Thatrsquos why facts, truth and trust are the most vital issues for the electorate.Herersquos a reminder of what the BBC should have told viewers. Vote Leave was fined pound, for breaking electoral law over spending limits. In March this year, it dropped its appeal against the fine. Vote Leave was fronted by Boris Johnson. Cummings was campaign director.The Electoral Commission said: ldquoSerious offences such as these undermine public confidence in our system and it is vital, therefore, that they are properly investigated and sanctioned.A day after Question Time aired, it emerged evidence relating to overspending, which could lead to criminal charges against Vote Leave, had been passed by police to the Crown Prosecution Service.The House of Commonrsquos Privileges Committee said Cummings had committed a contempt of Parliament by not appearing to give evidence when ordered as part of an inquiry into fake news.The fact that Question Time acted as a distributor for lies on an issue which is right at the very heart of Brexit and the forthcoming General Election makes the broadcasterrsquos failings ever more egregious.I donrsquot see bias at every turn with the BBC. Irsquove mostly great respect for the broadcaster in terms of its journalism and also its cultural output. When I see it attacked by both right and left, Leave and Remain, unionists and Yes voters, Irsquom pretty confident itrsquos doing its job and holding all sides of the political spectrum to account. Demonstrations against the BBC and hate campaigns against reporters run contrary to every democratic bone in my body. I see them as the first steps on the path to authoritarianism and populism.However, the BBC as a whole suffers from a fatal weakness: its automatic default position is to defend the status quo. When authority speaks, it accepts and parrots, it doesnrsquot question and interrogate. Radical voices are subjected to withering scrutiny, reactionary voices are treated with respect and dignity. This skews debate and immediately sets up imbalance.We saw the same problem here in Scotland during the independence referendum. The knee-jerk position was to subject the Yes campaign to forensic investigation, while broadly accepting most of what the No campaign said on face value. Both sides should have been put under the same pressure.There are also flaws built in to Question Time, which are now becoming damaging to democracy. The show isnrsquot about debate and getting to the facts, itrsquos TV clickbait. Itrsquos about screaming matches and outrage. Itrsquos a shock-jock show dressed up in the boring clothes of a politician.:Election : Jeremy Corbyn accuses Boris Johnson over NHSHere in Scotland, wersquore used to the games Question Time plays. Eyebrows were raised when a former UKIP member called Billy Mitchell appeared on the show for the fourth time in Scotland. Mitchell claimed he was invited by the showrsquos producer.The damage done to the BBCrsquos reputation by last weekrsquos show was immediate and deep. Shahmir Sanni, the whistleblower who exposed Vote Leave spending, said: ldquoOh my f**king God. Theyrsquore not even trying to hide it anymore! This audience member recalls Vote Leave breaking electoral law and Fiona Bruce literally lies saying lsquothey were cleared of those accusationsrsquo.Wersquoll be in serious trouble during this electionthe BBC shatters trust in itself. The public needs the BBC more than ever as an arbiter of whatrsquos true and whatrsquos lies in this era of mass manipulation and propaganda.Johnsonrsquos government is currently sitting on a report into Russian interference in British democracy. Dominic Grieve, the former Tory attorney-general, has called for its publication before the election.:Glasgow set to host BBC Question Time in run up to general electionThe Labour Party has began to question Dominic Cummings links to Russia. Emily Thornberry, shadow foreign secretary, wrote to the government asking about his connections to Russia and the level of security vetting to which hersquos been subjected in Downing Street.Amid all this, wersquove the truly grave threat Facebook poses to democracy. The social media giant will allow British politicians to run  ads on the site. To make the matter even more disgusting, the policy is being championed by Facebook executive Nick Clegg, the former LibDem deputy Prime Minister, who once spoke out about ldquothe colossal scale of the lies spread by the Leave campaign.Johnson and his new Tory radicals are also shameless in their deceit. Outgoing European Commission President, Jean-Claude Junker, said yesterday of the EU referendum: ldquoSo many lies were told, including by current prime minister, Boris Johnson, that there needed to be a voice to counter them.Chief among the voices countering lies should be the BBC. It shouldnrsquot be amplying hoods. Perhaps, one starting solution would be to change the format of Question Time by adding in a fact-checker service. While the  debate, a team of journalists could sit behind them double-checkingwhat they are saying is true. If they lie, fact-checkers should interrupt the show and tell viewers the truth. That would be a real service to democracy, and to the public, when we need it most.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year

title: self-sample-home-urine-test-increase-cervical-screening-uptake
story: Researchers have developed a way to identy pre-cancer lesions by analysing urine and vaginal samples that could be collected by women in the comfort of their own home.The ldquoself-sampling test proved popular with women taking part in the study, meaning it is likely to improve participation in cervical screening programmesmade widely available, they believe.Dr Belinda Nedjai, director of the Molecular Epidemiology Lab at Queen Mary University of London, said: ldquoThe initial use of self-sampling is likely to be for women who do not attend clinic after a screening invitation and countries without a cervical cancer screening programme.ldquoIn the longer term, self-sampling could become the standard method for all screening tests.ldquoThe study indicated that women much preferred doing a test at home than attending a doctorrsquos surgery.:Analysis: NHS too important not to be a political footballShe added: ldquoWe expect the self-sampling test to improve acceptance rates for cervical cancer screening, as well as reducing costs to health services and improving the performance of screening programmes.Dr Nedjai told the  NCRI Cancer Conference in Glasgow that the study was the largest to test for the S methylation classier, a chemical change to one of the four DNA base letters that make up the human genetic code.The test looks at the methylation of four HPVtypes most strongly associated with cancer and a human gene to calculate a risk score.It is estimated thateveryone attended screening regularly, % of cervical cancer cases could be prevented. If youre nervous, breathing exercises can help and nurses are trained to make you as comfortable as possible. #CervicalScreeningSavesLives #SexualHealthAwarenessWeek pic cVWwfXmmdash Public Health EnglandSeptember , In earlier research, they found that the test, when performed on cervical samples taken by healthcare professionals, was % accurate at detecting invasive cervical cancer, and % accurate at detecting pre-cancer in women who had an HPV positive test.In the new study,  women with abnormal smear tests or positive HPV results were asked to provide vaginal samples collected themselves using swabs.The researchers extracted and analysed the DNA in the lab and generated S scores.In urine samples, the S test was better at correctly identying women who did have pre-cancer lesions than existing HPV tests.:Chief of Royal College of Surgeons Edinburgh Alison Rooney forced out in no confidence voteThe S test correctly identied high-risk pre-cancerous cells in % of samples compared with % with an HPV- or  test.They believe it could be used in two ways ndash as a secondary test on HPV-positive women, or as a standalone test, where it correctly identied % of samples that were pre-cancerous.Dr Nedjai added: ldquoWe are currently working on new markers to try to improve the accuracy of the classier even further, but these findings represent an advance in cervical cancer screening, especially for women who do not attend the clinic, such as older women, or women who find the smear test too painful or who do not have access to a screening programme in their country. We think itrsquos promising.

title: birds put on a show at forvie reserve
story: Photographers have captured stunning images of wild geese and waders flocking to a local nature reserve.Images taken at Scottish Natural Heritagenational nature reserve at Forvie reveal the mass migration of wild birds from Iceland, Greenland and Svalbard.Stuart MacQuarrie, SNH’s Head of Nature Reserves, said: “To see a flock of geese as they lt off from their night-time roost is one of Scotland’s greatest wildle spectacles. It’s such a remarkable aerial display, made even better by the chorus of their high-pitched calls.“These amazing birds migrate as far as , miles to reach Scotland for their winter feeding, before ing to more northern climes in the spring. And there’s plenty of time for people to come out to one of our nature reserves over the next few months and see this marvellous display for themselves.” At Forvie, there are about  waders, including  dferent species, on the Ythan estuary over autumn. There are good numbers of redshanks, lapwings, curlews, dunlins, golden plovers and oyster catchers. An occasional rarity also shows up at Forvie, this year including a great egret, ten common cranes – and a terek sandpiper, only the second ever spotted in North East Scotland and the th in Scotland.The best places to watch them are from the hide at Waulkmill or the two laybys that overlook the estuary north of Newburgh on the A, where you can use your car as a hide and watch the undisturbed birds. There are also good views to be had by parking at theWaterside car parkand walking down the north side of the river on the Dune Trail.SNH’s Forvie reserve manage, David Pickett, explains:“These fantastic viewpoints make the Ythan one of the most accessible birdwatching spots in Scotland for waders.The best time to watch these amazing birds is approaching high tide, as the water is moving the birds closer to you.”For more info about Forvie nature reserve see:www.nnr-scotland.org.uk.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Engineers installing the two concrete shafts"  Progress at Kintore rail station site viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: first bus offers free journeys in honour of remembrance sunday
story: Bus operator First Bus is providing free travel to all armed forces personnel, veterans and cadets travelling to services and events across Scotland for Remembrance Sunday .All armed forces personnel, veterans and cadets showing their unorm and badges, or a recognised ID badge, can claim free travel up to pm on Sunday as they travel to and from Remembrance Day activities. The concession by one of Scotland’s biggest bus operator is in honour of all the fallen and the surviving veterans of conflict and it means that services across all three operating companies in First Aberdeen, First Glasgow and First Scotland East will be honouring the offer.Andrew Jarvis, Managing Director of First Scotland, said: “Remembrance Sunday is an important and solemn reminder of the sacrices made by so many in our Armed Forces and we wanted to do something to mark the occasion.“We have a number of veterans working for First Bus across all of our Scotland depots and we are very proud of their efforts and sacrice, so this is our way of saying thank you to them as well as honouring all men and women who choose to serve and protect the freedoms our country now takes for granted.“We hope this concession on our services will make it as easy as possible for as many Veterans, Armed Forces personnel and cadets to attend the ious Remembrance services and events up and down the country on Sunday to mark the occasion.”Gordon Michie, the head of fundraising at Poppyscotland, added: “Remembrance Sunday is an important moment in the national psyche. This is especially so for those who have selflessly served in our Armed Forces, many of whom have friends who have made the ultimate sacrice.“Providing free travel to veterans to help them attend Remembrance Sunday events across the country is a wonderful gesture by First Group and we commend them for this, and for their ongoing commitment to the Armed Forces community.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Bonfire Night is the busiest night of the year for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service." story: The new Kintore station is taking shape with engineers installing the concrete shafts for its accessible footbridge.The two ten-metre-tall, eight-ton structures were craned into position this week.Network Rail, and main contractor BAM Nuttall, are constructing the new £.m facility to reconnect Kintore to the rail network for the first time in  years.Funded by Transport Scotland, Aberdeenshire Council and Nestrans, the new station will have step-free access between s through the new footbridge and lts.Facilities at the station will also include a -space car park, including spaces for electric vehicles and disabled parking, bike storage facilities and connections into the local bus network.Kintore is due to enter service in May  and all Aberdeen-Inverness trains will call at the station.The original Kintore station opened in , but closed in  as part of the Beeching cuts.Reopening Kintore has been made possible by the double-tracking of the line between Aberdeen-Inverurie delivered as part of the Aberdeen-Inverness Improvement Project.Funded by the Scottish Government, the Aberdeen-Inverness Improvement Project is increasing capacity on the route between the two cities so more trains can run on the line.Graeme Stewart, Network Rail Senior Sponsor for the project, said: “The new Kintore station will reconnect the local community to the rail network for the first time in nearly six decades.“The construction of the new station is progressing to plan and we look forward to delivering the facility – and the travel opportunities it creates – for customers.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: campaign highlights road safety
story: As winter#s dark nights draw in Police Scotland are looking to shine a light on safety for vulnerable road users with new campaign Operation CEDAR.The initiative being run across the Highlands and Islands Division is aimed at improving road safety across the region. In Orkney, Police have joined up with Orkney Road Safety forum, to encourage cyclists to remain safe and visible, with not only education, but the handing out of bike lights.Police are reminding cyclists that along with obeying all traffic signs, traffic light signals and not cycling on pavements, they must equip their bikes with the appropriate lights and make sure they are lit when it starts to get dark.Officers in Orkney will be proactively looking to address cyclists who ignore the legislative requirement to illuminate their bikes in darkness, and will be providing bike lights to those who need them. Just over  pairs of bike lights have been purchased using funding from Police Scotland Safer Communities for this purpose.#Visibility is key to keeping cyclists safe on the roads and I would encourage cyclists to ensure they wear bright reflective clothing and illuminate lights on their bikes, both front and rear, in order to make themselves more visible to other road users,# said chief inspector, Matthew Webb.#This is equally applicable during the day, but more important at dusk and when it#s dark, to avoid collisions and warn other road users to their presence.#Some cyclists wear dark clothing and particularly on faster roads they can be almost invisible to drivers until they are close to them.#He added: #I recognise in this rural community that a lot of the measures are equally applicable to the equine community and they are more than welcome to make use of the same free offer.#This initiative has been supported by the Orkney Road Safety Forum who will assist with the distribution of these lights, which in addition to the police office, are available from the OIC hubs and Scottish Fire and Rescue Service Community Safety Advocacy.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: jobs boost for stronsay after fish farm proposals get the green light
story: Eight full-time jobs are set to be created in Stronsay after permission to construct two fish farms was granted.The farms at the Bay of Holland and Mill Bay will not only “safeguard the economic future” of the island, say operators Cooke Aquaculture but it may also lead to an expansion of its Orkney operations, Orkney Islands Council councillors heard.Chris Webb, the company’s environmental and development manager, told councillors during the latest meeting of the planning committee, that once the fish farms come up to full production, there will be a “signicant increase” in the number of jobs created at the company’s processing factory at Haston Industrial Estate.The increase in production may even facilitate a move to a new premises, Mr Webb said during discussions over the company’s Stronsay proposals.The two farms will take Cooke’s operational sites to  in Orkney and represent a huge boost for Stronsay’s economy.The company say that there is a desire to recruit local Stronsay staff to service the two sites which comprise of  cages each. title: second measles case confirmed onboard northlink ferry
story: A second measles case has been confirmed, linked to a Serco NorthLink Ferries service between Shetland, Kirkwall and Aberdeen.NHS Shetland has this week issued a “warn and inform” message to all passengers who travelled on three dates, including a northbound sailing which called in at Kirkwall.Those who disembarked and embarked the ferry in Orkney on Saturday, October , have been warned that they may have come into contact with the highly-infectious virus, say NHS Shetland.As well as the Saturday, October  sailing, warnings have been issued for all passengers who travelled on the southbound and northbound sailings on Sunday and Monday, October  and , which did not call in past Orkney.All crew members who travelled on the three dates have been notied.NHS Shetland is working with other relevant authorities including Health Protection Scotland to ensure that all control measure are in place to prevent further spread of the disease.The only way to prevent the spread of measles is to have the MMR vaccination, of which two doses is required to ensure full protection. It is possible that subsequent cases of measles could arise in susceptible passengers who have not been vaccinated.Measles is most common among young children who have not been fully immunised, and the disease can be spread through direct contact or through the air when they cough or sneeze.Passengers who travelled on the ferry are asked to be vigilant and content their GP or Public Health teamsthey develop a:copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: jacob-rees-mogg-apologises-grenfell-common-sense-comments
story: Jacob Rees-Mogg has apologised over comments he made about Grenfell Tower Jacob Rees-Mogg has ldquoprofoundly apologised for suggesting Grenfell victims should have used ldquocommon sense and ignored fire service guidance not to leave the burning tower block.His apology came after an LBC appearance on Monday, during which the Commons leader had discussed London Fire Brigadersquoslsquostay-putrsquo policy and said: ldquoIf you just ignore what yoursquore told and leave you are so much safer.ldquoI thinkeither of us were in a fire, whatever the fire brigade said, we would leave the burning building.ldquoIt just seems the common sense thing to do, and it is such a tragedy that that didnrsquot happen. -- --But after calls to apologise, Mr Rees-Mogg said on Tuesday: ldquoWhat I meant to say is that I would have also listened to the fire brigadersquos advice to stay and wait at the time.ldquoHowever, with what we know now and with hindsight I wouldnrsquot and I donrsquot think anyone  would.ldquoI would hate to upset the people of GrenfellI was unclear in my comments.The originalcomments were called ldquocrass and ldquoinsensitive by Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, and Grenfell United said his words were ldquoextremely painful and insulting to bereaved families.The Leader of the House of Commons suggesting that the  people who lost their lives at Grenfell lacked common sense is beyond disrespectful. It is extremely painful and insulting to bereaved families.mdash Grenfell UnitedNovember , On Tuesday, thehead of the London Fire Brigadesaid that ldquoknowing what we know now, the service would respond dferently to a Grenfell-like fire.LFB Commissioner, Dany Cotton, was answering questions at the London Assembly about the inquiry report into the  blaze that killed  people.She told the fire, resilience and emergency planning committee: ldquoClearly, knowing what we know now about Grenfell Tower and similar buildings with ACM cladding, our response would be very dferent.When asked how the service had changed its approaches, she added: ldquoNot only have we increased our attendancewe receive a call to a high rise fire, we increase the number of fire engines we send.What possesses someone to react to an entirely avoidable tragedy like Grenfell by saying the victims lacked common sense  People were terried, many died trying to escape. Jacob Rees Mogg must apologise for these crass and insensitive comments immediately.https:t.co QczWiyxkRmdash Jeremy CorbynNovember , ldquoIf there are multiple calls to the same building and the callers state the outside of the building is on fire we send an initial attendance of ten fire engines, plus officers, plus specialist appliances.Ms Cotton also expressed concern for the number of buildings covered in similar material to the Kensington tower.She told the committee: ldquoWe know that there are still several hundred buildings in London that are covered in ACM cladding [hellip] our concern is that action is not being taken quickly enough to remove that cladding which is a high risk.copy -.
